story:
Stephanie Patrick Dance

SPD was formed in 2012, when I was first invited to create a professional piece in Austin, Texas. The company now resides in the Bay Area, and it has been good to us!! The company was awarded Principal Creative and Performing Arts first-ever Starving Artists Award in 2015, two residencies at SAFE House Arts, and has been photographed by San Franciscan photographer, Karin Velasco.

What makes SPD different is its emphasis on a deconstructed musical theater formula, replacing scene text with spoken word poetry, and combining the presentational aspects of theater dance with the more internal, concert forms of dance. In an SPD show, you’re likely to see a duet between a modern dancer and a tap dancer, or a piece in which hip-hop and jazz collide, followed by a slam-style delivery of a poem.

SPD has big plans for its upcoming season, and we need you to make it happen!! To learn more about the company, visit www.StephaniePatrick.me, or email me directly at stephanie10103@gmail.com. We look forward to hearing from you!

Impact

It takes a lot of time and cost to become a functioning professional dance company! The biggest expense is paying the production team what they deserve for their hours of work--it takes lifelong training to become a professional artist, and most industry level professionals are underpaid. Please show my team your appreciation!

Funding Breakdown

$600.00 - We are asking only for artist compensation! Each artist involved in production will receive $10/hr for their work on the film. This amount does not include reimbursements for park fees, costume fees, or any other expenses. Our team is:
Diana Gameros (music)
Rafael Alba (cinematography)
David Kallison (cinematography)
Stephanie Patrick (dancing & editing)

What's in it for You?

As we are not currently a 501(c)3 non-profit organization, your donations are not tax deductible at this time. However, your help is crucial in making this performance come to life, and your impact will be appreciated! 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute. But that doesn't mean you can't help! Show that you believe in our campaign by sharing it on social media, sharing our website (www.StephaniePatrick.me), or sending it to someone who can donate on your behalf.

story:
The Play

Christian, Jewish, Muslim, Lizard-Worshipper: no matter how you were brought up, religion has affected us all. This show tells the true story of being a queer vegan in North Carolina who happened to be raised a little differently than everyone else. A mix of storytelling, song, characters, and dance makes this show a true “cult classic.” You will laugh, cringe, breath deep, and walk away with a whole new perspective on your own upbringing after seeing this show. 

 

Performance & Ticket Details

Please join me the day of the United Solo performance at the Studio Theatre at Theater Row!

September 22, 6pm
Tickets $35 (+tax & fee)

Tickets can be purchased through Telecharge (make sure you select the specific day of my performance - September 22 @ 6pm).

Located in Chicago?!  Come check out my Chicago Fundraiser Performance at iO Theater!

August 27, 8pm
Tickets $12 (Donate on this page for your ticket to the Chicago Performance!!) 

The Team

  • Rosie Moan (Writer/Performer) Rosie Moan is a Chicago based actor/comedian/writer. She can be seen improvising regularly at iO on the Harold team "Denver," every Thursday at the Annoyance with "Sight Unseen," every Saturday at Second City with "Madcap!" and with the Ensemble at Laugh Out Loud Theater in Schaumburg and Chicago. You can also catch her story-telling, doing solo work, and as one half of "Beowulf Improv." A few of her acting credits include Ona in Sweet Analytics (Tympanic Theater Company), Bev in It's Christmas Goddamnit (Annoyance Theater) and Holly in Vacation (Area IV). In addition to performing, Rosie is also a coach, a teacher, and leads improv workshops with the ImproveIt team. Rosie is a graduate of Emerson College and is represented by BMG Talent. Her favorite subjects are Beyonce and RuPauls Drag Race.
  • Tiffani Moore Swalley (Director) Tiffani is a director in the Chicagoland area and New York City. Her most recent works include productions at The New York City Fringe Festival (Girlish), The Annoyance Theater (I’m Just Like You: A Cult Story and Purity Ball: The Musical), as well as Period Piece: A Musical Reading featuring alumni from SNL and The Second City, and directing Second City’s House Ensemble, Infinite Sundaes (New Year, Same You). Her other credits include Assistant to the Director for The Second City’s Mainstage, Fool Me Twice Deja Vu, The Second City’s e.t.c Revue, Soul Brother Where Art Thou and The Second City National Touring Company's Blue Co. Tiffani is also a host and producer of the female fundraising show Got Her Back at MCL Chicago and a teacher at The Second City Training Center. She is a graduate of Northwestern University and is represented by Shirley Hamilton’s Talent Agency. 
  • Cat McDonnell (Stage Manager) Cat is a Chicago based artist and can be seen regularly on stage at the iO, Annoyance and MCL theaters. She is a graduate of The Second City's Conservatory and Severn Darden Graduate Program, and has performed with The Second City Theatricals aboard Norwegian Cruise Lines. Off stage, Cat is the Outreach and Development Director at MCL Chicago, where she is a co-creator/producer of the female fundraising show Got Her Back as well as the LGBTQ+ variety show Loud & Proud. Recently, she directed and music directed the productions Flipbook and Working Boi at iO Chicago and stage managed Period Piece: A Musical Reading featuring alumni from SNL and The Second City. Cat is a graduate of Providence College where she studied Theater and Music Performance, and she now plays in the Chicago band Side Pocket.
  • Libby Conkle- (Producer) Libby is a Chicago based Actor/Writer/Producer.  She has produced theater with Richard Frankel Productions, Ensemble Studio Theatre, Stage Right Productions, as well as her own written pieces. She can be seen on YouTube in her co-created web-series "The Real Deal" and in storefront theaters throughout Chicago.  She studied Drama and Producing at New York University and has her MFA in Acting from DePaul. She is represented by Gray Talent. 

United Solo Festival

United Solo™ is a New York-based company dedicated to the genre of one-person performance. Its goal is to present solo pieces, both local and international; discover original scripts; bring creators together; exchange perspectives; assemble performers, companies, and institutions, as well as other activities related to solo performance.

See more at their website: http://unitedsolo.org/us/imjustlikeyou-2017/

What We Need & What You Get

My total budget is $2,200. I am working many avenues to reach my goal: a fundraiser performance in Chicago, ticket sales at the United Solo Festival and from generous donors like YOU in my Indiegogo campaign!

  • Transportation and Lodging at the Festival- $800
    • Myself and my stage manager need to get ourselves and our set/props/costumes to New York for the show and we need somewhere to stay when we get there.
  • Festival Entry Fee - $700
    • The United Solo Festival is $700 for tech time in the space, my performance time in the festival, and for marketing tools provided for the show through the festival at large. 
  • Salaries - $400
    • This show wouldn't be what it is without a director and it wouldn't have any lights or music in the performance without my stage manager, I want to pay them for the time they give to make it possible 
  • Marketing - $300
    • We will be augmenting the festival's marketing services with our own targeted more specifically to an audience that would be interested in this show, its form and its subject matter.

Check out the perks to the right to see some specific opportunities to supporting our production.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help me spread the word! Share this campaign with your friends on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, and old fashioned word of mouth! Whoever you can tell, tell! The more people that know about it the better chance I have of reaching my goal!
  • Come to the fundraiser performance in Chicago on August 27th, 8pm at the iO Theater. Either buy your ticket for $12 on this page or get a ticket at the door, have a drink, and buy a raffle ticket for a chance to win some awesome prizes!
  • Come see the show in NYC on September 22 at 6pm and TELL ALL OF YOUR FRIENDS IN NYC to come see the show!!!!!

Thanks for checking us out and for your support!

story:
Why We're Here:

One night while working the graveyard shift at a roller disco in Marfa, TX, Donna and Colby are smacked with a surprise: The Apocalypse!  Skating through a honky tonk disco fugue, the ladies are left to figure out who they are, what it all means, and if anything even matters at all.

This is ROLLER DYNASTY.

We love that this play celebrates and investigates female friendship, and puts young intelligent women at the forefront!  In roller skates! We can’t wait to bring this brand new play to life in Los Angeles.  But for this, we need your help.

Things like rehearsal space, innovative designers, insurance, disco balls and rollerskates all cost money.  Below, we've included a pie chart of how we will divy up the money we raise.  The more we end up with, the higher our production value, ability to pay our actors, etc etc.  Check us out, and please donate!

story:
Promenade Opera Project

  • We are an innovative immersive opera company founded in 2017, are dedicated to opening relevant opera experiences to the greater Boston community, while advocating for emerging young artists. In today's arts culture, opera is often shrugged off as stuffy, boring, and unintelligible. We strive to reverse that thinking by producing immersive modern adaptations of classic operas with relevant themes and important stories for our time and allowing our artists to use their prodigious gifts to breathe life into classic works and allow them to be as new and important as they ever were.
     

  • Our third annual production, Bellini’s La Sonnambula, will be performed at Rengo Studios of Auspicious Phoenix Productions in Somerville, MA and sung in Italian.

  • Our immersive show, directed by Dan Rogers and designed by Joseph Wolfslau, will guide audiences through the dreamscape of Bellini’s beautiful sleepwalking bel canto masterpiece. That’s right! A moving production! Join us for the operatic experience of a lifetime and become part of the story!

  • For too long opera has been thought of as stuffy or elite. You can help us to bring the beauty, truth, conversation, and challenge of this art into our times and your life! Become a true patron of the artists and the arts. Join us!

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $5000 to pay our talented team of artists and designers!

    As a company we are committed to supporting young artists, not only by providing innovative performance opportunities, but also by prioritizing open book compensation. 69% of our budget goes directly to artist fees. Beyond that we also participate in a profit sharing program, in which our artists all receive an even percentage split on profits once production costs are covered. 

  • Beyond that, all additional donations will go towards space rental and production costs!

  • For generous contributors, we have company merchandise like Signed Posters of this show and previous productions.

    Moreover, we have a Virtual Ticket option! Whether you're out of town for the live performance, or want to be able to enjoy the show again and again, we will send you a video of the show from the audience's perspective for your viewing pleasure!

    Get the ultimate immersion experience, choose our Immersive Role perk and be IN the show! We will costume you, instruct you of your duties, and give you a chance to see the show from the inside!

    For our most generous tier of donors, we can even design a Bespoke Immersive Aria and Scene night at a location of your choosing! Just select the top most tier!

The Impact

  • In our current times of unrest and instability, we need art to see the beauty of the world, but also to challenge us and ask questions about how we interact with the world. POP, since its first production, has shared operas unique aptitude for opening us to exactly that conversation with diverse audiences in exciting new venues and situations!
     
  • This is our third main stage production! All of our productions have sold out every performance, paid all artists, and successfully helped to seed further endeavors - even including launching new ventures like commissioning new works to support not only young performers and designers, but also new composers!
     
  • From our humble beginnings putting on Justice or Mercy, we have since grown in each production to feature more new artists, explore more new spaces, and form more connections to the community!

Risks & Challenges

  • Opera is a risky business that frequently does not pay for itself, or if it does, it frequently does so by settling for less exciting or revolutionary productions!  We, however, have shown in our past productions that we do not have to accept that false dichotomy! Through inventive use of space and working directly with artists, we have found that we can make opera that is ethical, artistically fulfilling, AND fiscally responsible!
     

  • Through  careful budgeting and direct work with Boston artists to cut out the middle-man of agents, expensive travel costs, and unpaid Young Artist opportunities, we are able to put your money where it can do the most good  Working with talented young artists and offering them the chance to create something truly fantastic and new, we are able to work less expensively and guarantee that the beneficiaries of our work are the audience and the artists, rather than artistic establishment. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Visit our website: www.promenadeoperaproject.com
     
  • Please donate what you can! No gift is too small and all of your donation goes directly into creating new art and supporting young artists !
     
  • Don't forget to use the indiegogo share tools and visit our Square page: https://squareup.com/store/promenade-opera-project
     

And that's all there is to it!

Don't forget to use the indiegogo share tools and visit our Square page: https://squareup.com/store/promenade-opera-project

story:
Greetings! We are Coffee & Whiskey Productions! If you don't know us yet, you should, becuase we're doing things! Big Things! Well it depends on how you define big, but still-- things! 

Coffee & Whiskey was founded in 2014 by Matt Diel and Nic Wehrwein, two playwrights fed up with the traditional model of play readings, who decided to do something about it. Coffee & Whiskey wants to create something of real value for playwrights and audiences. Our goal is not only to create kick-ass entertaining theatre that makes you laugh and cry and sing along, but also to change the conversations that happen during new play development. Making them better... stronger... faster. We can rebuild them. We have the technology. But we need your help to do it.

 

What We Do

The Coffee & Whiskey season is made up of the Script Pub (our developmental reading series), and only recently added, The Productions (our series of fully produced works).

Over the last 4 seasons of the Script Pub, we've been fortunate to present fourteen fantastic plays, written by an amazing collection of playwrights from all over these United States, showcasing O'Neill finalists, National Latino Playwrighting Award Winners, and Kilroy List honorees. We’ve seen houses held together by faith and sweater yarn; we’ve seen cosmic love stories; we’ve grappled with family secrets and personal revelations, and it has all been unbelievably awesome.

Hand in hand with the Script Pub are the Productions: fully produced plays in limited-run engagements. 2017 was our inaugural year, in which we produced our first two original works, including the soon-to-be-world-famous Coffee & Whiskey signature show, Karaoke Night at Al Capone’s House of Pancakes! It has been amazing and gratifying and humbling. 

 

Your Role in The Madness

As always, what we're in search of is a gigantic pile of money. Once obtained, we will take that pile of money and place it in an Olympic-sized swimming pool, and dive in a la Scrooge McDuck. Once we finish doing that, we will take the money out of the pool and exchange it for goods and services. Thus will the Coffee & Whiskey season be born!

Seriously though, each and every thing we do requires money, for such things as:

  • theatre space
  • pizza
  • rehearsal space
  • the time and talent of the artists involved
  • seriously, a staggering amount of pizza

100% of the money we earn from this campaign will go directly to funding Coffee & Whiskey’s general operations fund—paying the artists, renting the spaces, set-building materials, all that coffee you drink at the Script Pubs, the whole shebang. And everything helps. Whether you have one dollar or a hundred dollars or ten thousand dollars, we can and will use it to make theatre happen. (Obviously, we’ll make a lot more theatre with the ten thousand dollars than with the one dollar, but hey, we work with what we have.)

And hey, to sweeten the deal for you, we've procured some sweet (and in some cases, unique) perks for your enjoyment! Stickers and T-shirts and mugs and pint glasses and limited-edition hoodies and probably some other secret things that we can’t talk about now because Russia is probably listening and you know they’re up to no good and probably SPECTRE is lurking around and maybe Dr. Claw also.

 

Why It’s Important

"Theatre is Conversation" is more than just a pithy motto—it’s our guiding principle. We believe in fostering the true, honest conversations that are so very vital to us as playwrights, as actors, as audience members, and as human beings. That only happens when everyone has an equal voice. At Coffee & Whiskey, we say come as you are, and screw all the people who say you can’t or shouldn’t. Raise your voice above theirs and join the conversation.

This is where they say we’re supposed to talk about our playwrights’ success and the great things we’ve accomplished and how generally cool we are. But we’d much rather let some of our collaborators speak for themselves:

“I have worked with Coffee & Whiskey Productions twice and had amazing experiences both times... without the feedback that I got from Coffee & Whiskey Productions I do not think I would have been able to make the progress on that play that I made.” – Casey Mraz, author of The Giraffe

“When so many submissions either go unanswered or are met with a simple automated rejection email, I greatly appreciated that they were willing to be honest with me, and that they saw something in my work that they felt was worth cultivating... I know for a fact that it is a much better play as a result of this process.” – Conor McShane, author of The Letter G

“...their minimalist production was eye-opening. The presentation, the audience reaction, the comments afterward and the new perspective, everything. As a direct result of all this, I turned Companions into an audio drama, which I think is the best single work I've ever done... I'm convinced that none of this would have happened in the same way if not for Coffee & Whiskey.” – Bob Koester, author of Companions

 

Risks & Challenges

The risk is that you’ll make us cry. It doesn’t sound terrible now, but trust me when I say you don’t want to see that—it's all super weird ugly crying faces with us (especially Nic), just really  unsettling to witness. And if we don't reach our goal, then rest assured that WE WILL CRY IN FRONT OF YOU. WE WILL HAUNT YOUR DAYS. EVER PRESENT, ALWAYS WEEPING. Blind date? We’ll be at the next table, crying. Big job interview? Sobbing in the corner behind the hiring manager. In the shower? Your towel will already be damp with our tears. Does that sound fun to you? Of course not, you’re not a monster.

Seriously, though, your risk is basically zero. You get to help the arts flourish, we get to do what we love, and some deserving playwrights get the critical feedback they need to take the next step and hopefully win a Pulitzer or a Tony or something. Who wouldn’t want to be a part of that?

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute directly, you can still help us by getting the word out. Tell everyone you know about Coffee & Whiskey and the work that we do, and let them know how to support it. Share it on Instagram, share it on Facebook, tweet that mess! Everything helps.
  • Next time you come to see a Coffee & Whiskey show, bring two people along-- we'll thank you for it, and they might also!
story_txt:
Greetings! We are Coffee & Whiskey Productions! If you don't know us yet, you should, becuase we're doing things! Big Things! Well it depends on how you define big, but still-- things! 
Coffee & Whiskey was founded in 2014 by Matt Diel and Nic Wehrwein, two playwrights fed up with the traditional model of play readings, who decided to do something about it. Coffee & Whiskey wants to create something of real value for playwrights and audiences. Our goal is not only to create kick-ass entertaining theatre that makes you laugh and cry and sing along, but also to change the conversations that happen during new play development. Making them better... stronger... faster. We can rebuild them. We have the technology. But we need your help to do it.
 
What We Do
The Coffee & Whiskey season is made up of the Script Pub (our developmental reading series), and only recently added, The Productions (our series of fully produced works).
Over the last 4 seasons of the Script Pub, we've been fortunate to present fourteen fantastic plays, written by an amazing collection of playwrights from all over these United States, showcasing O'Neill finalists, National Latino Playwrighting Award Winners, and Kilroy List honorees. We’ve seen houses held together by faith and sweater yarn; we’ve seen cosmic love stories; we’ve grappled with family secrets and personal revelations, and it has all been unbelievably awesome.
Hand in hand with the Script Pub are the Productions: fully produced plays in limited-run engagements. 2017 was our inaugural year, in which we produced our first two original works, including the soon-to-be-world-famous Coffee & Whiskey signature show, Karaoke Night at Al Capone’s House of Pancakes! It has been amazing and gratifying and humbling. 
 
Your Role in The Madness
As always, what we're in search of is a gigantic pile of money. Once obtained, we will take that pile of money and place it in an Olympic-sized swimming pool, and dive in a la Scrooge McDuck. Once we finish doing that, we will take the money out of the pool and exchange it for goods and services. Thus will the Coffee & Whiskey season be born!
Seriously though, each and every thing we do requires money, for such things as:

theatre space
pizza
rehearsal space
the time and talent of the artists involved
seriously, a staggering amount of pizza

100% of the money we earn from this campaign will go directly to funding Coffee & Whiskey’s general operations fund—paying the artists, renting the spaces, set-building materials, all that coffee you drink at the Script Pubs, the whole shebang. And everything helps. Whether you have one dollar or a hundred dollars or ten thousand dollars, we can and will use it to make theatre happen. (Obviously, we’ll make a lot more theatre with the ten thousand dollars than with the one dollar, but hey, we work with what we have.)
And hey, to sweeten the deal for you, we've procured some sweet (and in some cases, unique) perks for your enjoyment! Stickers and T-shirts and mugs and pint glasses and limited-edition hoodies and probably some other secret things that we can’t talk about now because Russia is probably listening and you know they’re up to no good and probably SPECTRE is lurking around and maybe Dr. Claw also.
 
Why It’s Important
"Theatre is Conversation" is more than just a pithy motto—it’s our guiding principle. We believe in fostering the true, honest conversations that are so very vital to us as playwrights, as actors, as audience members, and as human beings. That only happens when everyone has an equal voice. At Coffee & Whiskey, we say come as you are, and screw all the people who say you can’t or shouldn’t. Raise your voice above theirs and join the conversation.
This is where they say we’re supposed to talk about our playwrights’ success and the great things we’ve accomplished and how generally cool we are. But we’d much rather let some of our collaborators speak for themselves:
“I have worked with Coffee & Whiskey Productions twice and had amazing experiences both times... without the feedback that I got from Coffee & Whiskey Productions I do not think I would have been able to make the progress on that play that I made.” – Casey Mraz, author of The Giraffe
“When so many submissions either go unanswered or are met with a simple automated rejection email, I greatly appreciated that they were willing to be honest with me, and that they saw something in my work that they felt was worth cultivating... I know for a fact that it is a much better play as a result of this process.” – Conor McShane, author of The Letter G
“...their minimalist production was eye-opening. The presentation, the audience reaction, the comments afterward and the new perspective, everything. As a direct result of all this, I turned Companions into an audio drama, which I think is the best single work I've ever done... I'm convinced that none of this would have happened in the same way if not for Coffee & Whiskey.” – Bob Koester, author of Companions
 
Risks & Challenges
The risk is that you’ll make us cry. It doesn’t sound terrible now, but trust me when I say you don’t want to see that—it's all super weird ugly crying faces with us (especially Nic), just really  unsettling to witness. And if we don't reach our goal, then rest assured that WE WILL CRY IN FRONT OF YOU. WE WILL HAUNT YOUR DAYS. EVER PRESENT, ALWAYS WEEPING. Blind date? We’ll be at the next table, crying. Big job interview? Sobbing in the corner behind the hiring manager. In the shower? Your towel will already be damp with our tears. Does that sound fun to you? Of course not, you’re not a monster.
Seriously, though, your risk is basically zero. You get to help the arts flourish, we get to do what we love, and some deserving playwrights get the critical feedback they need to take the next step and hopefully win a Pulitzer or a Tony or something. Who wouldn’t want to be a part of that?
 
Other Ways You Can Help 

If you can't contribute directly, you can still help us by getting the word out. Tell everyone you know about Coffee & Whiskey and the work that we do, and let them know how to support it. Share it on Instagram, share it on Facebook, tweet that mess! Everything helps.
Next time you come to see a Coffee & Whiskey show, bring two people along-- we'll thank you for it, and they might also!

story:
Who we are

We are a group of SMU Meadows School of the Arts Alumni who are ready to return to our roots and collaborate without distraction. We are coming from all over the U.S. to mount a minimally-produced, brisk cutting of Romeo and Juliet to be performed the last weekend in January/early February in an intimate space. We don't believe we need concept to make this play exciting or relevant, and we chose Romeo and Juliet for its lyricism, energy, comedy, and unbridled passion. When we last worked together, many of us weren't far from the ages of some of these characters; we knew each other as teenagers. Now, in our thirties, we're ready to dive in with experience, technique, and trust. We hope this is the first of many collaborations. Emily Ernst, Joshua L. Peugh, and Christopher Rutherford with co-direct with original music by Ivan Dillard and Ian Ferguson.

The Cast
The Prince/Paris - Alexander James MacAlpine
Benvolio - Scott Shomaker
Montague/Mercutio/Apothecary - Ian Ferguson
Romeo - Brandon Walker
Lady Capulet - Joan Korte
Lady Montague/Nurse - Jaquai Wade Pearson
Juliet - Emily Ernst
Tybalt - Flip Croft-Caderao
Capulet/Friar John - Michael Federico
Friar Lawrence/Peter - Christopher Rutherford 

Co-Director/Choreographer - Joshua L. Peugh
Fight Director/Movement specialist - Sara Romersbeger
Graphic Designer - Xavier Castillo 
Original music by Ian Ferguson and Ivan Dillard

Co-Directed by Emily Ernst, Joshua L. Peugh, and Christopher Rutherford 
 

What we need

  •  $8K will cover everything. This is half the average budget for scenery alone for the least-expensive Off-Broadway production. We are going absolute bare bones, with focus on the performances. We will fund most of our own travel and housing.
  • 90% of these funds go to pay our artists: two incredible, sought-after equity actors (Michael Federico and Ian Ferguson), eight equally talented non-equity actors (two of whom double as directors), a stage manager, and an internationally-renowned fight director (Sara Romersberger) and choreographer (Joshua L. Peugh). The rest covers our $500 liability insurance policy, some marketing, and a few essential costume pieces and props.
  • Inspired by the democratic work of Jacques Lecoq and Shakespeare's own company, Emily Ernst and Christopher Rutherford will co-direct with Founding Artistic Director of Dark Circles Contemporary Dance, Joshua L. Peugh. Ian Ferguson's original music completes this interdisciplinary collaboration.
  • If we don't reach our goal, artists make less. The project will happen either way!
     

The Why

We want to make Dallas a destination for the arts. Many of us have gone away to larger markets and want to bring what we learned back home. Your funds will help us come together for a month-long residency, where we can collaborate without distraction.

We want to give back. We will donate everything beyond our budget in ticket sales to a Meadows scholarship set up by Katie Featherston (Paranormal Activity), who graduated in '05.

We want to grow. We believe the ability to bring Shakespeare to the life is like going to the gym as an artist: it's an opportunity not only create work we love, but also to train as we focus on the voice, movement, and textual comprehension required to bring this muscular language to its full potential. 


The How

As our movement Professor Bill Lengfelder put it: "That you are even attempting the script without the trappings of traditional theater is absolutely like the existential, spontaneous, youthful, 'doing it all for love' that Romeo and Juliet is about." We agree. And like Grotowski, we are deliberately limiting the size of our space: 99 people perf performance.

We've got experience, work ethic, and guts. We can do a lot with a little. We are prepared to mount a show at about a fourth of the budget typically required of a full-length production in our market. We have eliminated costs wherever possible:

  • Deeply discounted space for rehearsals and performances
  • Donated housing (including by some of us!)
  • Actors who double as directors and designers
  • Very minimal costumes 
  • No set 
  • Small cast
     

Special Thanks


Special thanks to Kitchen Dog Theatre in Dallas and The House Theatre in Chicago; two SMU groups who inspired us to make our own work. To Nebraska Wesleyan University for lending so many graduates to this project! To Wolford McCue for his generosity, Ryan M. Hunt for his photography talent, Mike Yeshion for the hook-up, Michelle Leblanc for the magic, Christopher Michael Ham for friendship and support, Graham Dodds for lending his culinary talent to this project, Mikal (Evans) McAllister for totally conceiving and editing of our video, and current Chair of The Division of Theatre, Dr. Gretchen Smith, for her vision of how this initial group could grow into something bigger. Thanks also to Bill Lengfelder for offering a class to anyone who donates at the $100 level.

story:
My name is Vinny Stodder. I am a composer, lyricist, book writer, and arranger. I came to New York from Berklee College of Music in Boston to pursue my dream of creating and producing original Broadway musicals.

The Berkeley Dissolve is the original musical I have been writing for the past four years. It is ready for its first public presentation. 

The Berkeley Dissolve tells three intertwining stories set in Berkeley, California in 1974: A disenchanted former Black Panther turned New Age therapist struggles to help a failing student escape the Unification Church. Two students are entrusted to be nannies for the Church of Satan’s head priest’s daughter. A former child actor’s struggles with heroin lead him to embrace the dawning Gay Rights movement. The characters are all products of a radical time and place where it was dangerously easy for young people searching for an identity to get lost on the way.

This is my first public presentation of the show, and it will be a concert reading with a live band and professional actors. 

My hope is to raise $2800. This will help me pay my actors, my production team and band for the concert and assist with the costs of renting a venue and printing scores and scripts. 

 

The Impact

The hope is this concert reading will spark excitement for the show to grow and be seen by even larger audiences! 

Your contribution will support this exciting new musical that pays tribute to the diverse and innovative music of the early seventies while telling the compelling stories of young people involved in the historic movements of this epochal time. The original score is a celebration of artist such as Crosby Stills and Nash, Joni Mitchell, The Who, Stevie Wonder, Elton John and David Bowie to name a few.

Risks & Challenges

Berkeley Dissolve is a large, ambitious work that cannot be produced on a shoestring budget. It offers a fresh and exciting perspective that will appeal to a variety of audiences. It’s a show that promises to succeed on several levels- through music, historical context and the striking parallels between dream seekers of the seventies and the many who share those same hopes and quests for change today.

Other Ways You Can Help

Donations of any amount are gratefully welcomed! You will be supporting a great show, one that will have appeal even for those of you who are not necessarily fans of traditional musical theatre. 

Together we can bring something special to the stage!

story:
HEY!

We are Somehow 9am Productions, a production company dedicated to helping new artists produce new works. We're here because we are raising funds for our FIRST production as an official company, A My Name Is Allison by Emery Schaffer, directed by V Greene!  

We are new and still learning, but one thing we do know is that we will be compensating our artists. We are so lucky to have artists graciously dedicated their time to us, and we think we should pay them for it.

Here's What We're Thinking:

We are trying to raise around 1,500 dollars. We know. That's a terrifying number. Here's where all this cash is going:

Providing a stipend for our actors, director, stage manager, set designer, lighting technician, video, etc... 

Renting rehearsal space.

Providing a reimbursement cushion for purchases made to better this production. 

The unknown financial burdens that will surely arise (because #livetheatre).

It is SO IMPORTANT for artists to feel valued and appreciated for their work. That means paying them.

The Future:

Every cent we make here will go directly into the betterment of this production AND our small fledgeling company. Additionally, we are currently undertaking other exciting projects such as an EP, podcasts, short films, and more. The more we make here, the more we get to help future emerging artists! And with your help, we will be able to be a self-sufficient company, someday. We have a crap-ton of dreams about this, please help us achieve them! 

"But What If You Don't Reach Your Goal?"

We're learning. We're new. We don't know what the future holds. The good news is that we are relentless and passionate. We will make it work, no matter what is raised or not raised. That's what makes Somehow 9am Productions unique.

Short On Personal Funds?

Hey! That's okay! We get it and have been there (and are there right now!)! Here's how you can help us without spending money:

SHARE! You never know who's out there. Sharing this page on Facebook, Instagram, via email, or however else you reach your masses is immensely helpful and super appreciated.

Indiegogo has share features! This is a super-easy, one-click way that you can help. 

Thank you, from the bottom of our hearts. It means the world to us. 

Love,

Somehow 9am Productions (Mack and Emery)

story:
Our Story

'Ophelia' is making its London debut at The Old Red Lion Theatre this February for their new Spring Season. We're part of their 'Where Are We Now?' Festival, a collection of theatre about the world we live in today and where we go from here.

This is a show about how we romanticise and idealise women, love, sex, and suffering in our culture, and how hard it is to break out of abusive and unhealthy relationships even long after they’re over.

We're thrilled to be bringing 'Ophelia' to a new audience, and very pleased to announce that we will again be collecting donations for Women's Aid after each performance. 

Women's Aid provides refuge and support for survivors of abuse. You can find out more about their vital work here:

https://www.womensaid.org.uk/about-us/

Risks & Challenges

As emerging artists, we need help with funds to bring our production to London and ensure that we have as numerous and as high quality publicity materials as possible. We're a small team based in the Midlands and this is our first attempt at breaking into the London fringe theatre scene without any external backing. We want to make as wide and as good an impression as we can. As you can imagine, self-producing a fringe show in London (or anywhere) requires as much support as you can get.  Your money will go towards the costs of our marketing, technical support, and venue hire.

About Us 

There may not be many of us behind this production, but we are determined to make it work and have a wealth of experience between us as writers, performers, directors, and producers. We've all worked in fringe theatre across the country (including the Edinburgh Festival) and on small-to-mid-scale UK tours.

Our producer is heavily involved with two prominent regional theatre companies, and is a member of the Birmingham JMK Directors Group, having been awarded their assistant director bursary to work on 'The Lovely Bones' at the REP in 2019. Our writer is part of Young Pleasance and has had her work performed at Theatre503, the Omnibus, and Columbus State University. And our director is a member of the Young Vic Directors Program, Birmingham JMK Directors Group, Nottingham Playhouse's AMPLIFY, and was long-listed for the RTST Peter Hall Directing Award 2019. 

So whether you've never heard of us before but are intrigued by our show and its message, or whether you've seen the production in Leicester and liked it and want to support our next steps, feel free to click the donate button.

Rewards

We also have a range of rewards for donations including: mentions in our programme notes, handwritten thank yous, signed posters, decorative print-outs of Shakespeare sonnets, and bespoke illustrations. For full details, please check out the link above. 

Summary

Every penny counts, so please donate what you can! If you can't donate, please help spread the word about our fundraiser and upcoming London run using social media and the Indiegogo share tools. We've worked really hard on this show and want to share it with as many people as we can. 

Thank you so much for any contribution you can make! 

Lots of love from all @opheliatheplay!

Facebook: @opheliatheplay

Twitter: @ophelia_play

Instagram: @ophelia_play

About the Show:

Ophelia falls in love. Infatuated, she dreams romantic visions of new landscapes and vibrant colour. Then he leaves. Lost, rejected and struggling to make sense of the world, she finds herself standing at the water’s edge. Its darkness seems irresistible… somehow beautiful.

Quietly echoing Shakespeare’s Ophelia, this evocative one-woman show gives us a 21st century woman, grappling with sexuality, mental health and the nature of abusive relationships. Emma White’s new play daringly uses the audience to help tell Ophelia’s story, whilst scrutinising our obsession with beautifying female tragedy.

Praise for 'Ophelia':

“evocative and disturbing… playful and [controlled]” Come To The Pedlar

Audience Responses:
"Beautiful and tragic depiction of what love can do to a girl”
"I really loved how intimate the experience was” 
"I could listen to Emma talk forever!”

Find out more and book tickets at:

https://www.oldredliontheatre.co.uk/ophelia.html

We want to make as wide and as good an impression as we can. As you can imagine, self-producing a fringe show in London (or anywhere) requires as much support as you can get.  Your money will go towards the costs of our marketing, technical support, and venue hire.About Us There may not be many of us behind this production, but we are determined to make it work and have a wealth of experience between us as writers, performers, directors, and producers. We've all worked in fringe theatre across the country (including the Edinburgh Festival) and on small-to-mid-scale UK tours.Our producer is heavily involved with two prominent regional theatre companies, and is a member of the Birmingham JMK Directors Group, having been awarded their assistant director bursary to work on 'The Lovely Bones' at the REP in 2019. Our writer is part of Young Pleasance and has had her work performed at Theatre503, the Omnibus, and Columbus State University. And our director is a member of the Young Vic Directors Program, Birmingham JMK Directors Group, Nottingham Playhouse's AMPLIFY, and was long-listed for the RTST Peter Hall Directing Award 2019. So whether you've never heard of us before but are intrigued by our show and its message, or whether you've seen the production in Leicester and liked it and want to support our next steps, feel free to click the donate button.RewardsWe also have a range of rewards for donations including: mentions in our programme notes, handwritten thank yous, signed posters, decorative print-outs of Shakespeare sonnets, and bespoke illustrations. For full details, please check out the link above. SummaryEvery penny counts, so please donate what you can! If you can't donate, please help spread the word about our fundraiser and upcoming London run using social media and the Indiegogo share tools. We've worked really hard on this show and want to share it with as many people as we can. Thank you so much for any contribution you can make! Lots of love from all @opheliatheplay!Facebook: @opheliatheplayTwitter: @ophelia_playInstagram: @ophelia_playAbout the Show:Ophelia falls in love. Infatuated, she dreams romantic visions of new landscapes and vibrant colour. Then he leaves. Lost, rejected and struggling to make sense of the world, she finds herself standing at the water’s edge. Its darkness seems irresistible… somehow beautiful.Quietly echoing Shakespeare’s Ophelia, this evocative one-woman show gives us a 21st century woman, grappling with sexuality, mental health and the nature of abusive relationships. Emma White’s new play daringly uses the audience to help tell Ophelia’s story, whilst scrutinising our obsession with beautifying female tragedy.Praise for 'Ophelia':“evocative and disturbing… playful and [controlled]” Come To The PedlarAudience Responses:"Beautiful and tragic depiction of what love can do to a girl”"I really loved how intimate the experience was” "I could listen to Emma talk forever!”Find out more and book tickets at:https://www.oldredliontheatre.co.uk/ophelia.html

story:
Hey There :)

My name is Courtney Flores & I am the founder of Wall Breakers. I have been dancing for over 11 years and have been blessed to be able to use my gifts and talents to make a positive effect on others. This is just one project of many that I hope will inspire many and make a difference in the dance industry. This webseries is an effort to change lives of passionate dancers and break the molds of the industry. With your help, I am able to bring a beautiful vision to life and share my passion with others! Your help is appreciated more than you know! :)

What We Need

There are a few things we need and your donations will help!

-We need professional equipment to properly record the webseries that we plan to use as a pilot submission (cameras, microphones, audio players)

-We want to create a tanktop for our dancers & mentors to represent this project so we can spread the word

-We would like to pay our staff, director, cinematographer, graphic designer & mentors for their hard work, time, contributions, and talents.

All money raised will be used to make this webseries as professional as possible and to get it out there for many eyes to see and many lives to be touched.

What is Wall Breakers really all about?

Wallbreakers’ mission is to transform dancers from the inside out. By testing our insecurities, fears, and motives, we will naturally overcome obstacles that have held us back emotionally in life and physically through dance. Through a series of challenges, we will continuously strive to find freedom and break down walls that have been keeping us from our fullest potential. We want to share our growth through the journey to complete liberation with the hopes of being an inspiration to others.


10 episode web series that takes place at a different public location every episode. 
10 dancers go through the webseries working on a different part of their inner struggles through a mixture of choreography, freestyling and structured audition situations given by our 10 expert mentors.
 
Founded by: Courtney Flores
Director: Gaby Lemus
Staff: Emmie Bauer & Skye Woods
Artwork by: Taylor Ramsey (Royalty Vision)
 
Other Ways You Can Help

Like us on facebook! WALLBREAKERS1

Follow us on twitter! @Wall_Breakers

Subscribe to us on youtube! www.youtube.com/WallBreakers1

Share this project with your friends & family so you can make my dream come true :)

For other sponsorship volunteers or questions about the project, feel free to email us at breakingwallsthrudance@gmail.com

story:
Our Story

Panfish dÃ©buted in 2010 with its production "4-Play: 4 One Act Plays" to rave reviews. This year, the company will proudly present a Canadian classic with its production of â€œThe Melville Boysâ€. Panfish Productions was founded with the core value of "Building Community Through Artistic Mentoring." Our company brings in industry professionals as mentors in all areas of the production to aid in the training and development of the emerging talent working on the show. Panfish productions is experiencing tremendous growth and is carving out a niche in the Toronto theatre community. We are a company of dedicated individuals who are passionate about the arts and the artistic community.  Panfish Productions provides amazing opportunities to train and network with established artists, producers, casting directors, stage management and other technical staff, while putting on a top-notch theatrical production

The Impact

By supporting our campaign, you will help grow a company with a strong desire to give back to the community.  You will help provide opportunities for emerging artists to practice and display their craft, and aiding in the development of a whole community.

What We Need & What You Get

The money we raise here will go towards our production expenses. These include (but are not limited to):

  • Theatre Rental
  • Rehearsal Space Rental
  • Rights for the Play
  • Director Fees
  • Sets/Costumes/Props
  • Publicity and Promotion
  • Other Incidental Expenses

**note** While reaching our "Goal Amount" will not actually cover all the production expenses, what your support will do,  is provide us with a working budget for this show so we can get things done.  Also, your suport will help offset what we have to deduct from ticket sales/revenue and will provide a starting point for Panfish's next production.  Not having to start 'from scratch' each time means that we can grow and develop the company and the artists working with us much faster.

Any amount helps, so if one of the levels doesn't work for you, feel free to hit 'contribute' and name your own amount.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are looking for people to help out with things like promotion, fundraising and other production aspects. For more information please contact us at info@panfishproductions.ca

story:
Our Story

In the Summer of 2009 Lisa Beth Dery and Lori Watt founded Frolicking Divas, an independent theatre company by women for women.  Their first production was Criminal Hearts by Jane Martin which had a successful run at the Havana Theatre in Vancouver.  In the Spring of 2010 they partnered with Penny-A-Line Productions and the Art Matters Society to bring Eve Ensler's The Vagina Monologues to Spectral Theatre and the WISE Hall in Vancouver and the Massey Theatre in New Westminster.  Now, we are very excited to be mounting our third production, Neil Simon's The Odd Couple (female version) at the Jericho Arts  Centre in Vancouver.  Show opens March 7, 2012.


The Impact

Artists do it for love, right? However the cost of mounting a play is daunting. From renting rehearsal space and the venue, to buying wood to build the set to even securing the rights to produce the play - it all costs money.

Along with the actual play costs there is also the expense of promoting the play. Posters, newspaper ads, programs and radio spots let people know where and when the show is also cost a lot of money.This show is a co-op venture so all the actors are working without guarantee of pay, they are doing this because they love the project and this will help gain them experience and recognition.Artists do it for love - but with your help - they won't have to go into debt as well. Please help - even ten dollars will make a big difference.



What We Need & What You Get

There are many people that are involved in making this production truly great.  We require funds to make that happen.  The funds received will go to pay for:


Our Director (contract fees with CAEA)

Stage Manager

Samuel French (the rights to do the play alone are over a thousand dollars)

A Publicist

Fees for the Theatre space

Ads 

Stills Photographer & Graphic Designer (for poster work)

Posters Printing

Poster Distribution

Flyers

Brochures

Costume designer and costumes

Props

Stagehands 

SOCAN fees

Lighting Technician

and

Our Actors!

Other Ways You Can Help

(Unleash the DIWO! -- 'Do It With Others' by asking folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Don't forget to remind them about the share tools!)

story:
Edinburgh Festival Fringe, August 6-15 and 19-27 at 1pm @ Venue #203: Princes Mall  


The Play

The Translator's Dilemma is a one-hour drama designed to raise awareness about the dangers of asbestos and the plights of those suffering from asbestos-related illnesses in Scotland, Italy and around the world. Ottavia, a lecturer in translation studies, is covering a class for a friend. When she opens the notes, however, she realises the content is closer to home than she could imagine. Can she give a lecture on asbestos without revealing her own deadly secrets?

Inspired by the true story of multinational asbestos executives who allowed the deaths of thousands of Italians, this play explores the fallout of a killer mineral, and its effect on a young woman's life. Performed in Italian and English, by two actors and one overhead projector.


Performances

The show will be on as part of PBH's Free Fringe programme at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. We're in venue number 203 which is at Princes Mall (the shopping centre just next to Waverley train station) and the show runs from August 6-15 and 19-27th at 1pm. Tickets are free, which is one of the reasons that we are fundraising with IndieGoGo.


About Asbestos

Asbestos poses an international problem that kills 100,000 people worldwide every year, affecting millions of people on multiple levels. It causes grave health concerns, presents an environmental risk as a hazardous material that is extremely difficult to dispose of, and continues to be a workplace safety problem. Our production aims to provoke audiences and encourage them to think about concrete things they can do about these issues when they walk out of the theatre. We hope The Translator's Dilemma will serve as a springboard for foundations, victims associations and the general public to work together towards an international ban on asbestos, to stop the further production and use of the substance, and to raise awareness about an issue that has been silenced for decades.


The Translator's Dilemma Needs Funding

As you can well imagine, it will take money to create our production and putting on a show at the fringe isn't cheap. The production team are working for free on the project but we would like to at least pay our director, actors and technicians for their travel expenses. As such, much of our budget will go towards those three weeks of rehearsal and three weeks of performances. The show won't have big sets, but we still need costumes, props, a projector and a screen. We also need to pay for marketing costs, such as printing flyers and posters. If we manage to make more than we need to put the show on, we'll be giving the rest to a Scottish asbestos charity.


Please note that we are performing at the Free Fringe, which means all tickets to our show are FREE. Consider just donating the price of a standard Fringe ticket, which is $17 (£10), which will go directly to our costs, instead of a box office or venue.


And though we're fundraising in dollars, remember that all of our costs are in pounds sterling. Here's a quick conversion guide, so you can see how far your money will go:


$ 10:  £ 6

$ 20:  £ 12

$ 50:  £ 30

$ 100:  £ 61

$ 500:  £ 308


Other Ways You Can Help

Let other people know! Share the link on your facebook, forward the email, tell people... The more people that see our page the more likely we are to get the pennies together to make it happen! Also, if you know any companies or organizations that might like to get involved (victims' associations, law firms, health organizations, environmental groups, etc.), please contact us.


The other obvious way you can help is to come see the show and spread the word! It's completely free and right in the middle of town during the Fringe.


Questions?

Just ask. You can email info@scandaltheatre.com, contact us on Twitter (@scandaltheatre), find us on Facebook, or via www.scandaltheatre.com

story:
“Jurassic Park: The Musical” is a small theatre production filled with whimsical humor and a child-like sense of wonder.

The play was written and is being directed by Max Brown and Ryan Cortez, college students living in Denton, Texas. Max and Ryan have also made a unique, original music score for the musical under their band alias known as “Savage and the Big Beat.” The music sounds like a mix of 1920s show-tunes and current indie pop sounds. For an example here’s a link to the Savage and the Big Beat website http://savageandthebigbeat.com

The production began in January 2010 and the production should be performed by May 2010.

story:
ARE YOU READY FOR MORE SEX-ED BURLESQUE???

We hope so because Chlamydia dell'Arte is coming back with a brand new show in September 2013! Gigi and Meg will be performing six shows only in the 2013 FringeArts festival in Philadelphia. Featuring comedy, songs, dance, striptease, and more, Chlamydia dell'Arte: MORE Sex-Ed Burlesque is a riotous sex-ed class unlike anything you've ever seen before!

This is no joke.

Did you know that higher rates of sexually transmitted diseases and infections happen in tandem with low exposure to sex education? Well, duh! Makes perfect sense, right? Did you know that nursing homes are seeing outbreaks of STDs? Do you know how many people can't adequately even identify the component parts of their own reproductive system, including parts of their external genitalia? 

We're not having it!

We Chlams believe that laughter is the best medicine for a lot of what ails us. When we sit in a room together and laugh with each other and share our stories, we all learn something. That's the method behind the madness of this show.

And hey - people have noticed.

“Impressive: Naglak and Williams are so exuberant and unaffectedly positive about sex that in their hands, none of the material seems dirty.” –The Washington Post

“Meghann Williams and Gigi Naglak’s well-crafted show is sexy, funny and genuinely educational.” – Philadelphia City Paper

“Combines the racy, raunchy, and outlandish with some truly thought-provoking moments.” –Washington City Paper

We need your help to make this happen.

This show only happens because of the amazing community that surrounds it, from the fabulous artists who create our costumes and light our faces and keep the music pumping to the folks who tell us their stories on video to the people who come out every night to see us. 

We need costumes. We need condoms. We need dildos. We need fans and pasties. We need a stage manager, a costume designer, and a lighting designer. We need to get the word out using postcards and social media and posters in shop windows. And all of this requires a certain financial investment that can't entirely be covered by ticket sales.

We're looking to raise $2000 from now through the end of FringeArts. You should know that every single penny we raise here will go directly to the show: to the artists involved, to the props, to the costumes, to the condoms we give people every night.

Furthermore, funds donated from generous folks like you help us keep ticket prices low, making the show more and more accessible to those who might not have the means to afford an expensive ticket. Did you know there's a direct connection between poverty and unplanned pregnancy, sexual assault, disease, and so on? Yeah, we weren't surprised either.

There  are so many ways you can help! 

We would be so grateful if you would consider making a monetary donation to this project. And don't worry -- we're going to show you our gratitude! Take a look at the perks described here. Sounds like fun, don't you think? You can even get friends together to donate at a higher level if you're hell bent on a fan dancing lesson or a customized Barbie. 

But hey, we totally get it if making a donation isn't in the cards for you right now. No problem! Do you know someone who might be interested in this campaign or in this show? Send it along! Sharing tools are at your disposal to spread the word on social media. And we would love to see you in the theatre during FringeArts! Tickets are on sale now: http://fringearts.ticketleap.com/chlamydia-dellarte-more-sex-ed-burlesque/#view=calendar.

story:
WAYS TO KILL ETHYL

Grandma died at the potluck…but the meatballs were just delicious!

A dark comedy by Grayson Moore, premiering at Factory Theatre this July for the 2012 Toronto Fringe Festival.

THE PLOT.

Siblings decide to hold a potluck in order to murder their grandmother, who was asleep in the backseat of the car their parents crashed in. Unfortunately, their pompous half-brother is also attending and killing Ethyl becomes more difficult than they had expected.

See how Ethyl dies in this dark comedy about storytelling, triviality, and organized dining events.

THE CAST.

Peter Spence, Jeff Ulrich, Krista Hovsepian, Susan Q Wilson & Tyler Champagne

WHO IS ETHYL?

Ways to Kill Ethyl is an experiential, one-act (60min) dark comedy written by Grayson Moore.

WTKE will premiere at the 2012 Toronto Fringe Festival (July 4th-15th) at Factory Theatre. We have a total of 7 performances over the course of the 12 day festival. (See showtimes below).

Recently, storytelling that is widely available to large audiences has become diluted by ploy after ploy in order to maximize how 'broad' it can be. The apathy of consumption dictates the apathy of production. Ways to Kill Ethyl is a dark, hilarious reminder that the audience is at the mercy of the story, not the other way around.

There are two things that are gaurenteed:

1. Ethyl will die.

2. You'll never forget this play.

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET.

We are in need of $1100 in funding.

Your contribution will go towards these associated costs:

-Renting rehearsal space (200+ hours of rehearsal)

-Props & costumes

-Printing & copying of our posters, programs & postcards

-Feeding the cast... (not to be confused with cats)

THE PERKS.

*When you check out, in the comment section, please specifiy:

a) The purchaser's name

b) The show date of your choosing

$25 MEATBALL
- 1 ticket to the show date of your choosing
- Special thanks in our program
- “Meatball” status on our website
- 11 X 17 poster, signed if you want it to be.

$50 ACCOMPLICE
- 2 tickets to the show date of your choosing
- “Meatball” status on our website
- A copy of the script.
- 11 x 17 poster

$100 FAMILY VALUES
- 4 tickets to the show date of your choosing.
- “Meatball” status on our website.
- You can be listed as anything you want in the program (ex. Animal
   Control- John Smith) - as long as it's appropriate-ish

- A covered and spiral bound copy of the play

- 11 x 17 poster.

$250 THE SPIRIT OF ETHYL
- Everything in the Family Values perk plus:
- Executive Producer credit.
- E.P. WTKE T-shirt.

$1100 SOMEONE?
- A firm handshake and a room temperature glass of milk.

*What is “Meatball” status?
Basically, you have the option to have your name, or whatever name of your
choosing, written on a meatball graphic and then posted on our website under
the “Meatball” section.

WHAT ELSE CAN YOU DO?

If you are even looking at this page we are already in your debt, but the most incredible thing you can do to support the show is to come see it. Bring a friend, or two , or more - if you can. If you like it, tell people. If you don't like it, tell people. That's only fair. Any time you can share our videos, images, facebook, website, etc - it goes a long way. We appreciate every effort of promoting Ways to Kill Ethyl!

WANT TO ADVERTISE IN OUR PROGRAM?

Please email WTKE at waystokillethyl@gmail.com for more information.

SHOWTIMES.

*All WTKE performances will be held at Factory Theatre (125 Bathurst Street, Toronto ON M5V 2R2)

Thursday. July 5. 6:30pm - 7:30pm

Saturday. July 7. 11:00pm - 12:00am

Monday. July 9. 1:00pm - 2:00pm

Wednesday. July 11. 7:30pm - 8:30pm

Friday. July 13. 9:15pm - 10:15pm

Saturday. July 14. 12:30pm - 1:30pm

Sunday. July 15. 3:30pm - 4:30pm

BUY TICKETS HERE: https://www.fringetix.ca/scripts/max/2000/maxwe...

Running Time: 60min
Genre: Comedy
WARNING: Graphic Violence, Mature Language

Please be sure to check out our other links below for more information and fun!

story:
MacBeth Meets Montessori!


SkullDuggery Theatre is preparing to present its 26th Show, Bright Ideas by Eric Coble. In the tradition of SkullDuggery’s mission, Bright Ideas will be an Omaha premiere bringing fresh new theatre to its community. The performances will be produced in the heart of Downtown Benson (a suburb of Omaha) and a percentage of profits will go to benefit the restoration of the Benson Theatre.

How far would you go for your child? For Genevra and Joshua Bradley, the question is no longer hypothetical. Their three-year old son, Mac, is next on the waiting list to get into the Bright Ideas Early Childhood Development Academy—and everyone knows once you’re in there, your life will unfold with glorious ease. Josh and Gen have had to scramble all their lives to get this far… and now they are one fatal dinner party away from the ultimate success as parents: The Right Pre-School. You may never look at pre-school—or pesto—the same way again.

In a world where job training starts at age 4, Bright Ideas explores the lengths parents will go for their children’s success. We all strive to provide the best opportunities, the best schools, the best life. But when fighting for perfection blurs the lines of morality and sanity, giving our children what’s best becomes our (and their) destruction instead. Knowledge is power, and like in Shakespeare’s Macbeth, the obsession with power is corrupting. This show, although hyperbolic, can be the impetus for conversation about what it means to be a good parent.
 


In asking for donations, we are striving to cover the costs of costumes, props, advertising, rights to the show, and the effort to provide financial support to the local talent. Omaha has a diverse theatre community with a limited amount of paid professional opportunities. One of our goals is to provide that support consistently through our productions.

Our production will be performing at the Pizza Shoppe Collective, a non-traditional performance space. It is home to many artistic events and our set, props, and dressings needs to be flexible around a consistently changing schedule. Flexibility extends within the production of Bright Ideas as there are 17 locations that need to be realized in the performance space. To make this happen and keep with the theme of the play, our pre-show design will utilize a makeshift backdrop and oversized children’s blocks in creative and colorful fashion. From Poisonous Pesto to Green Birthday cake, the prop list is fairly extensive. Similarly, there are over 17 characters played by only 5 actors within the show, each requiring a detailed costume that sets them apart and uniquely distinguishes each role. Additionally, the sound and light design will play a pivotal role in transforming the performance space. To see our vision come to life for Omaha audiences, your contribution is greatly needed.
If do not reach our entire goal, we will use what we have to create the design of the show and the world will implode.

To develop the concept for Bright Ideas, we focused on three main elements: The inspiration that the script drew from Shakespeare’s Macbeth; the childish-ness of the main character’s actions; and the journey of these characters from the hum-drum to cataclysmic and catastrophic disaster. The play starts with a bare stage, just some blocks to create a non-descript locale (similar to Shakespeare’s Old Globe Theater). As the events tumble forward, the performance space becomes more and more colorful, diverse, and dynamic. What were only benches at the start become the world around the characters. Mirroring the building blocks of a preschooler, they start building up the world around them. In the end, those blocks ...come crashing down into a giant mess of balloons, streamers and emotion, as the world of these characters crashes down around them.


SkullDuggery has successfully produced 25 shows, most of which have had critical acclaim and garnished several awards and nominations from The Theatre Arts Guild and Omaha Entertainment Awards. Our previous season had 2 shows listed as the best of Omaha Theatre from the Omaha World Herald with 2 additional shows that season being on the honorable mention list. The Majority of productions to date have earned enough to pay its artists and we want that tradition to continue.
In addition to your financial contribution, you can also help by joining our facebook group at facebook/skullduggerytheatre.com and spreading the word!

story:
To celebrate our fifth anniversary, the Boston Book Festival wants to bring a taste of literature to people in settings where it is least expected-- bars, pubs, cafes, and subway cars.  Our goal with FlashLit is to surprise unsuspecting folks with a little literary magic aiming to add some “re-enchantment” to everyday life. Partnering with some of Boston’s hottest fringe theatre troupes, scenes will leap off the page into a live performance in venues scattered throughout the city’s diverse communities: from Central Square to Charlestown, Southie to the South End. 

How It Will Work

The project will send a group of actors "undercover" during the five nights leading up to the Boston Book Festival, featuring a different local theatre company each night (including Liars & Believers, New Exhibition Room, Theatre on Fire, and Vagabond Theatre Group). At first, these actors will be indistinguishable from every other person in the setting, casually sipping a drink and reading from a book. When the actors begin to interact and raise their voices in a full-throated delivery, the bar or subway car will find itself an involuntary host to a famous moment from a novel or play. After a few minutes, the scene will end, the actors will disperse, and things will return to normal. The play is done. There will be no warning, no advertising, and few traces of the BBF to be found once the actors leave, save for a couple copies of the book from which the scene is taken and a BBF bookmark as a clue. The event will come and go like a mirage. 

What We Hope to Accomplish

This project is truly meant to bring a piece of flash pop-up theatre – a lightning-speed performance – out into the neighborhoods of Boston, in familiar establishments frequented by locals. Whether the piece is vaguely familiar to listeners or completely unfamiliar, we hope to leave people thinking—and wondering. More than anything, we want to ignite a passion for literature and the infinite possibilities which writers make possible through their crafting of words. Will anyone figure out that the performance was brought to them by the BBF?  Who knows. That’s not really the point.  We want to bring the magic of literature to people in their everyday lives. 

Challenges

As with any theatrical performance, the actors risk being pelted with rotten vegetables. Or, confronted with blank stares. But seeing how people respond is an essential part of the project. This unanticipated live performance will be made doubly interesting by the improvised and unpredictable reactions from the “audience.” It requires performers who can perform a literary adaptation while improvising with the surrounding crowd. By breaking down the barrier between performer and spectator, however, the risky reactions could turn into a great reward.

Rewards

Bringing a performance into a non-traditional environment means reaching an audience that may not frequently enter a bookstore or a theatre. Setting these pop-up plays on a piece of the “home turf” provides the Boston Book Festival and the theatre companies associated with the project a chance to reach outside our traditional boundaries. This sense of discomfort and spontaneity will add an extra, lively dimension to the performance. We hope that by creating something unexpected and rare, viewers will have a memorable experience that encourages a sense of ease when approaching literature and the arts.

Why We Need Your Help

In the performing arts, presenting ethically means paying the artists involved in a piece. Keeping in mind that each piece will have a director and multiple actors putting in rehearsal hours before their on-site performance, your donation will enable us to pay a competitive stipend for the theatre-makers involved in FlashLit. We also plan to purchase several copies of each book from which we adapt a scene to leave behind at the performance site for the extra-curious spectator to pick up and continue reading.

story:
Short Summary

Artesan is an exciting and emerging dance company, with a vision to transcend dance by awakening the world through wonder.  Featuring artists from around the globe, Artesan fuses technical backgrounds in contemporary, ballet and urban dance. Founded in 2006 by Artistic Director and Choreographer Summer Odell, Artesan’s aim is to touch the depth of the human spirit through movement. Odell creates unique and spellbinding choreography that brings a fresh and exciting viewpoint of the world to the stage.

 This summer Artesan has been invited to perform “Parallels of Another Universe” at the prestigious Inside/out Series at The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. Jacob's Pillow has a long and beautiful history as America's longest running dance festival. Performing on this stage has been a dream of Artesan's founder for many years and to have it happen this soon is beyond a dream come true. Many of the greatest professional dancers and dance companies of the last 80 years has danced at the Pillow. The New York times hails Jacob's Pillow "the dance center of the nation."  You can see a picture of the stage as well as read more about the festival here:  http://www.jacobspillow.org/festival/overview/insideout/index.php   

Your support will be key in bringing Artesan's dream to perfom at the Inside/Out Series at The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival into reality.  We cannot do it financially without the help of generous patrons and fans like you.

Our Dancers performing in the Inside/Out Series include: Esther Hansen, Eero Taina, Claudia Schiavon, Brandon Burgess, Natasha Morken, Fred Vassallo, Michael Potter

 

What We Need & What You Get

Trip Cost Break Down (Bare Bones Budget):

Rehearsal Space: $1,230

Hotel $1,680.00

Food $640.00 

Company Airfare $6,600 

Company Transportation: $650.00

Music licensing fees, Insurance, Basic administrative costs: $1,200.00

This is our bare bones budget without our artists even getting paid!

An additional $8,000 will be needed to pay our artists so while it's not included in our $12,000 goal, anything above and beyond will go towards paying our artists, hiring additional artists, creating new work, administrative costs, preparation and funding for our regional and world tours, and the building of our local outdoor stage for community performances. 

Perks:

As a symbol of our huge gratitude for your generosity and support, we provide a variety of exciting perks, including a paid trip with us to see our Inside/Out Series at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival debut!  Among other perks to enjoy are: a chance to sit and watch a company rehearsal, an opportunity to participate in a company dance class, and an intimate cocktail party with Artesan which includes a film screeing of our performance at Jacob's Pillow.

 

The Impact

Your contributions will provide a foundation of financial momentum for Artesan Dance Company to perform on the east coast this summer as we continue creating new work and new performances for the 2013-2014 season.  Without your help, we won't be able to continue on or pay for our incredible dancers and backstage staff to stay with us and will sadly have to close our season with our performance on the east coast.    

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to financially contribute you can still help.  Please share our link about our campaign to others to spread the word about us which helps to reach a wider audience and "Like" us on Facebook.  

We truly believe that we have some of the best and most loyal supporters on the face of the planet and we want you to know that every gift we receive is appreciated and celebrated and helps to bring us one step closer to our goal of awakening the spirit and inspiring wonder and hope all over the world. Thank you so much for your support!

story:
Who We Are/What We Do

All great art seems to have a history or genesis in controversy.  “The First Book of the Bible” was  created by theatre majors Christian Haigis and Wesley Zurick for their senior project at the School for Creative and Performing Arts in Cincinnati, OH. Christian and Wes had long been riveted by the stories of the Old Testament and were excited to interpret the ancient tales with their brand of humor and biting wit. The musical, however, was banned by the school administration, despite support from parents, local community art organizations and several teachers. The First Book of: The Bible, even with age restrictions and warnings, was deemed inappropriate fare when The Vagina Monologues and For Colored Girls got the green light in past years.  Luckily, it was perfect fare for Cincinnati’s popular and progressive summer Fringe Festival. The premiere of The First Book of: The Bible was the first sold-out show of the 2011 Fringe and went on to win the coveted “Audience Pick of the Fringe” award .

Christian and Wesley followed up with a sequel, Exodus, in the summer of 2012 which thrilled well-attended audiences at the Monmouth Theatre company in Newport, Ky. Christian went on to film school at the University of Texas in Austin, TX, and Wesley started his 2nd year at the Atlantic Acting School in NY. They have reunited this summer to bring their original show to the Big Apple with another set of incredibly talented actors, actresses and musicians.

The Holy Impact

Have you ever wondered what the holy heck happens to the money you put in that basket at Sunday Mass? The world may never know. Fortunately, we welcome the inquiring with open arms! Here is a list of things your money will be going towards:

  • Theater space ($1,800)
  • Costuming/Makeup
  • Props
  • Special Effects
  • Lights
  • Advertising!

Go Tell It On The Mountain!

We would like to thank you for your contributions and attention! However, if you can't donate anything, no hard feelings. We only ask that you please spread the holy word to your friends on the interweb! The fate of the universe in is YOUR hands, now!  

 

Facebook:

https://www.facebook.com/HolyBiblePlay

 

Tickets!

http://exodus.ticketleap.com/holybibleplay/
story_txt:
Who We Are/What We Do
All great art seems to have a history or genesis in controversy.  “The First Book of the Bible” was  created by theatre majors Christian Haigis and Wesley Zurick for their senior project at the School for Creative and Performing Arts in Cincinnati, OH. Christian and Wes had long been riveted by the stories of the Old Testament and were excited to interpret the ancient tales with their brand of humor and biting wit. The musical, however, was banned by the school administration, despite support from parents, local community art organizations and several teachers. The First Book of: The Bible, even with age restrictions and warnings, was deemed inappropriate fare when The Vagina Monologues and For Colored Girls got the green light in past years.  Luckily, it was perfect fare for Cincinnati’s popular and progressive summer Fringe Festival. The premiere of The First Book of: The Bible was the first sold-out show of the 2011 Fringe and went on to win the coveted “Audience Pick of the Fringe” award .
Christian and Wesley followed up with a sequel, Exodus, in the summer of 2012 which thrilled well-attended audiences at the Monmouth Theatre company in Newport, Ky. Christian went on to film school at the University of Texas in Austin, TX, and Wesley started his 2nd year at the Atlantic Acting School in NY. They have reunited this summer to bring their original show to the Big Apple with another set of incredibly talented actors, actresses and musicians.


The Holy Impact
Have you ever wondered what the holy heck happens to the money you put in that basket at Sunday Mass? The world may never know. Fortunately, we welcome the inquiring with open arms! Here is a list of things your money will be going towards:

Theater space ($1,800)
