story:
Who Are We? 

We, Beck Heiberg and Mette Loulou von Kohl are two performers who have decided
to collaborate on a performance piece together!

Beck, born in Copenhagen, Denmark is a dancer trained in urban and underground
styles. He is known for androgynous and high performance quality in his work.  He
is currently located in Paris, France.

Mette Loulou was born in New York City. Although trained in traditional acting
techniques, she now uses her love of dance and visual art in her performance work.
She has lived in Morocco, Romania and Copenhagen, and now resided in New York
City.

The Project

The project is a movement based performance that uses dance and actions to
navigate our exploration of the “in between.”

Please check out our video to learn more!!!!

We Are Going on Tour!

We will be going on tour around Europe from the beginning of July to the beginning
of August. We need your support to make this happen!!! If you like what you see
please help us out! Any amount is a huge contribution!

If your funds are too small, there are still ways you can help. Spread the word on your facebook, twitter, tumblr or between email contacts. Recommend us to your friends and send us good wishes and good luck.

xxxxxxx Thank you!!!!!!!!!

If you are interested in having us perform in you city please get in touch!
Beck Heiberg- Beck.Heiberg@gmail.com
Mette Loulou von Kohl- mlvkohl@gmail.com

story:
Have you ever fulfilled a life-long dream?  My name is Heldine Aguiluz, and as young as I can remember, I have had the passion for performing.  Most, if not all, performers envision sharing their talents on the stages of New York City.  And I am soon to be one of the lucky few to achieve that goal!  But I need your help to do it.

About "Daze of My Life"

"Daze of My Life" is my first-ever written piece.  So not only do I get to perform in Theatre Row in NYC, but I also get to share my personal story with the audience.

I have been working on "Daze of My Life" for almost 2 years, and it was not easy.  "Daze" is a solo performance that shares experiences I have had throughout my life that shape who I am today and the way that I view myself.  It deals with important issues, such as self-image, sexual abuse, and adoption, along with sharing some of my Filipino culture.

I honestly didn't think my story was interesting or important.  I thought people would find it boring and self-centered.  But after my first performance for my solo class showcase, I got such a great response from the audience that I decided to take my piece to the Hollywood Fringe Festival.  I later applied and got accepted to perform "Daze" for the LA Women's Theatre Festival (LAWTF)!  It was such an amazing surprise, and the positive support for my show just kept stacking up.  I guess I was making a difference in people's lives because, to my amazement, so many people could relate to my story in some way!

This year, I wanted to challenge myself even more by applying to Fringe NYC - a world-renowned and highly competitive theatre festival -  so that I could join the other talented performers in the NYC spotlight and share my story.  But to no avail; I did not get accepted.  I was disheartened until I got a letter from them sharing their disappointment in not being able to fit me into this year's festival schedule.

Luckily, I had also applied to the United Solo Theatre Festival (USTF) in NYC - and got in!  My acceptance into the USTF reminded me to never lose faith in myself and to use rejection as a means of growing.  It also reinforces the importance of sharing one's story (not just mine).

Helping me to get my story out to the NYC audience is a stepping stone for not only me, but for everyone who wants to share their life experiences and art.  I want to spark people's creativity and courage, show them the possibilities of what they can do with their passions, and encourage them to step out of their comfort zones.

What Your Support Does for "Daze"

Everyone knows that New York City is an expensive place to visit, let alone live!  Aside from pursuing the performing arts (which, in case you didn't realize or forgot, does not pay much to most), I work two part-time jobs.  Unfortunately, after paying for the cost of living and student loans, it is hard to fund my trip on my own.  Your supportive donations will help to pay for some of the festival fees and travel costs (flight, accommodations, in-city transportation, and food).

Even though "Daze of My Life" is a solo performance, I did not work on it alone.  Without Debra De Liso, "Daze" would probably never exist.  Debra taught me the art of solo performance and supported me every step of the way from the first day that I walked into her class two years ago up until now.  And she offered to help me with little to no monetary requests.  I would love your help in providing Debra De Liso with as much compensation as I can for all of the time she put into helping me with this project.  If anything, I want to be able to pay for her travel costs (because she is coming to NYC not only as my director, but also as my stage manager!).

"Daze of My Life" has been a constant work-in-progress.  The shows that I performed at the Hollywood Fringe and the LAWTF were shorter than the piece that I will perform in NYC.  I thought it would be a great idea to share the newer version of "Daze" with not only a NYC audience, but with people in LA - my hometown.  A portion of the funds received will go towards the production of an LA show.

I need a total of $2,500.  My goal for IndieGoGo is to raise at least $1,500.  In summary, all of the money will go towards paying for the following:

  • United Solo Theatre Festival fees
  • flight costs for my director (Debra De Liso) and me
  • publicity
  • transportation costs while in NYC
  • food during our NYC stay
  • accommodations
  • paying my director (Debra De Liso) for all of her hard work
  • producing an LA show of "Daze of My Life"
  • paying IndieGoGo a percentage of the money raised

Details about Rewards

About the LA Show of "Daze of My Life"

Some of the rewards include tickets to an LA show.  My original plan was to produce and perform an LA performance of "Daze of My Life" before I leave for New York City.  I am waiting to hear back from a theatre to see if there are any available dates that work before my NYC show and will update this area to include the details.  If a show pre-NYC is not possible, then the LA show will happen after the NYC show.

About Karin Schneider Photography

Karin Schneider is a long-time college friend.  The picture I am using to promote "Daze of My Life" was taken by her!  Being the generous and supportive friend that she is, she also offered her time to take pictures of people who donate $100 (see the $100 reward for details).  Check out her website: http://www.schneider-photography.com

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have the money to donate?  I completely understand.  Don't worry - you can still show your support by doing the following:

  • Spread the word to help me reach as many people as possible!  Share the campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or blog.  Email family and friends.  Tell people you know in NYC to come and watch my show!
  • Have you seen me perform "Daze of My Life" before?  If so, write a testimonial about it in the comments section to share your thoughts and reactions.  Your feedback can help influence others to donate and to watch the show!

NEW! - Referral Contests

As I mentioned above, I appreciate your word of mouth about my campaign - so much that I wanted to show my appreciation and reward you for your efforts through a referral contest!

GENERAL RULES:

  1. If you have an IndieGoGo account, make sure you are logged in and use the link provided to you on this page.  That link has a special ID number to track your referrals.  ONLY THE NUMBERS LISTED FROM YOUR REFERRAL LINK WILL COUNT.
  2. If you do not have an IndieGoGo account, make sure that the people you refer leave a comment on the page, saying that you referred them.  ONLY PEOPLE THAT COMMENT WILL BE CONSIDERED A REFERRAL.  ONLY ONE COMMENT PER REFERRAL.
  3. "Referral" = a person who has visited the page (does not need to have donated)

September 26, 2013 - CLOSED

For those who have already donated to my campaign:

  • For every 10 referrals, you get a ticket to the LA performance of my show!
  • For every 2 contributions made as a result of your referral, you get a ticket to the LA performance of my show!
  • 4 total max tickets per person (ex.  20 referrals + 4 contributions = 4 tickets)
  • Note: If you paid for the $10 "Laughs" reward, the ticket from that is not included in your 4 max for this contest.  Only tickets from referrals and contributions are considered.

For those who have not donated to my campaign:

  • For every 15 referrals, you get a ticket to the LA performance of my show!
  • For every 3 contributions made as a result of your referral, you get a ticket to the LA performance of my show!
  • 4 total max tickets per person (ex. 15 referrals + 9 contributions = 4 tickets)

(Possibly more referral contests to come!)

Details about USTF Performance

When: Saturday, October 19, 2013 at 9 PM

Where: 410 W. 42nd St. NY, NY 10036

Tickets: 212-239-6200 or http://www.telecharge.com

More Info.: http://www.unitedsolo.org

Thank You!

Whether or not you believe in my show and support it, I appreciate you and the time you spent to come and check out my campaign!

Hoping for the best,

Heldine

story:
Who We Are

Mine is Yours Theatre Company is an ensemble of classically trained, Los Angeles-based artists. Through inventive productions of classic and contemporary plays and casting choices which defy convention, we seek to celebrate the complexity of women, and to offer actresses and actors the opportunity to play a wider variety of roles than the theater and film industries normally afford them. We want to explore the transformative power of theatre, revel in the bare magical moments that only happen on stage, and illuminate the vital and irreplaceable ways in which theatre speaks to life in the 21st century.

A few years ago, Hannah, Hayley, Julie and Mary Ellen worked together for one wild summer of Shakespeare in Topanga, CA. We loved working together, we loved our new theatrical family, but we were not in love with the general lack of Shakespeare roles for women... Thus, Mine is Yours was born!

Our inaugural production as a company is a 90-minute, 7-actor Twelfth Night which will open on Twelfth Night and run for three nights only (January 6-8, 2014) at a gorgeous chapel in downtown Santa Monica!

Your donations will help us pay for our venue and compensate our amazingly talented cast and crew for their valuable time and energy! Most importantly, it will bring this fun and inventive production of, in our opinion, Shakespeare’s most complexly hilarious comedy to downtown Santa Monica and to Shakespeare lovers, new and old!

For more information about us and our company, please visit our website: http://mineisyourstc.wix.com/miytc

Where Your Donations Are Going

So, to bring this beautiful production to fruition, we are in need of:

  • $1,000 for our venue -- the gorgeous chapel!
  • $1,200 to pay our crew and performers for their time and talent.
  • $300 for marketing materials -- posters, flyers, etc.

Other Ways You Can Help

Do you LOVE what you've read and seen so far, but you just can't donate? WE UNDERSTAND! There are a couple of other ways to help us out:

First of all, come see the show! We know you'll love it, and if you stick around after the show, we'll even give you a big hug (who doesn't love hugs?!) Presale tickets are $10. Tickets will be $15 at the door. http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/534876

And B of all, you can demonstrate your support for our show and company by "Liking" us on Facebook, telling your friends and family about us, and using the Indiegogo share tools! Thank you for helping us spread the word! 


We can't wait to see you all on Twelfth Night! 

Love, 

Mine is Yours & The Cast and Crew of Twelfth Night

story:
Who Are We? What Is This? 

Strange Bird Theatre Company is a freshly-hatched collective with an artistic commitment to work that highlights the myriad complexities of human relationships and tackles difficult themes to spark social dialogue. We seek texts that illuminate often-stigmatized social issues and, by bringing them to the forefront, combat their status as taboo or unapproachable. Strange Bird is therefore committed to diverse voices and representation as the truest reflection of human experience. We are comprised of emerging and established artists from a wide range of professions and walks of life. 

This campaign represents a fundraising effort for our first mainstage production, going up this December 14-16th: Ruby Rae Spiegel's Dry Land. A somber, hilarious, difficult investigation into the lives of two adolescent girls on a swim team in small-town Florida, this play represents the complexities of female friendship, sexuality, and body ownership at a time when all control seems to be slipping away.

As a brand-new collective, we are endlessly grateful for any contributions that will aid in honoring this story to its fullest. Donations are a fantastic way to support us, and so is joining us at Shetler Studios this December!

What We Need & What You Get

All donations to this project will go directly towards our production costs, including but not limited to space rental, props, costumes, performance rights, set piece rental, and marketing. Our goal is set at $2,800, which aims to cover not only the aforementioned expenses, but also a bit extra for donation to Planned Parenthood of NYC! (As this play deals with themes of abortion, sexuality, and women's health, we feel it is critical to our mission of socially-conscious theatre to contribute to such non-profit organizations.) Our estimated costs stand at $,2000, at which point any remaining funds will be donated. 

See below for an idea of the difference your contribution can make, and what strange and exciting perks await at various levels of giving. Every donor will receive a shout-out in our program! 

  • $10 - Freestyle
    • Buys us small props and costume pieces (goggles, swim caps, the many snacks we consume onstage)
    • Perks: Our unending love and gratitude! Plus a social media shout-out, and a program thank-you! 
  • $25 - Backstroke
    • Buys us multiple costume pieces and additional fun props
    • Perks: You will be mailed a hand-written love note, and noted in the program!
  • $50 - Breaststroke
    • Covers some of our printing and marketing costs (programs, posters, etc.)
    • Perks: Get a very special thank you as a fellow "Strange Bird" Donor in our program!
  • $75 - Butterfly
    • Covers the entire rental for one of our large set pieces 
    • Perks: In addition to a "Strange Bird" Donor credit, get an original Dry Land poster, designed by our very own Tatyana Aravena, and signed by our cast & crew!
  • $100 - Dive in
    • Pays for the production rights for one of our performances! 
    • Perks: In addition to "Strange Bird" Donor credit, you will receive some colorful, charming, and mischievous original art drawn by Michelle Siracusa.
  • $250 - Deep End
    • Covers transportation and set-up expenses for our entire set! 
    • Perks: In addition to "Strange Bird" Donor credit, you will receive a gift basket with surprise goodies!
  • $500 - Gold Medal
    • Covers three days of space rental for our rehearsals and performances! 
    • Perks: You will receive a Producer credit & two complimentary tickets to the show for the night of your choice!

Please be assured that we plan to mount this very important production regardless of whether we meet our set goal, and all donations will still make an impact! 

The Impact

Dry Land is a story exploring two teenage girls' choices about their lives and bodies at a time when women's stories, sexuality, and bodily autonomy are consistently degraded and devalued in our culture. Bringing their stories to life means not only the chance to provide meaningful, thoughtful entertainment for people, but to spark critical conversations and provide representation onstage that many of us do not get to witness in our everyday lives. We hope that everyone can find power in seeing a piece of themselves recognized in this play. 

On a more long-term scale, your donations are also helping facilitate the launch of Strange Bird as a collective that hopes to exist for many years to come, continuing to produce conversation-sparking theatre and to give voice to diverse human experiences. This is a true grassroots endeavor, and it starts with the support and participation of audience members like yourselves! We want our projects to feel that they belong to everyone! 

Risks & Challenges

Starting a theatre company is no easy task! Dry Land comes with the risks of any first production. Our cast and crew's diverse range of professions and career paths have presented time constraints. As we have no standing funding (yet!), the upfront costs have been high for us, but we are determined to raise that money and more, the difference to be donated to Planned Parenthood. Another challenge of being a newly-minted company is a limited capacity to market and advertise. We are building awareness and support from scratch, and your help is fundamental not only in covering practical costs, but in spreading the word for Strange Bird!

We plan to continue to fundraise through our performance dates in mid-December, and to seek funding from additional sources including small grant programs that are committed to new creative projects. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, there are other great and simple ways you can help:

  • Spread the word about Strange Bird! If you identify with or are interested in our mission and story, please let your friends and loved ones know! Every listening ear helps, as does every Tweet, Facebook status, and Instagram post! 
  • Talk loudly about us around the water cooler at work! On your Tinder dates! At Thanksgiving dinner around another strange bird!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools! Click those buttons and send our fundraising link to as many people as you can!
  • COME TO THE SHOW!! BRING A WHOLE ENTOURAGE! This effort means little without audience members to witness it. Our production goes up at Shetler Studios in "The Bridge" at 244 West 54th Street, New York, NY. Show times are as follows: 
    • Friday, December 14 - 7pm
    • Saturday, December 15 - 7pm
    • Sunday, December 16 - 3pm & 7pm

And that's all there is to it. Please help Strange Bird take flight!
story_txt:
Who Are We? What Is This? 
Strange Bird Theatre Company is a freshly-hatched collective with an artistic commitment to work that highlights the myriad complexities of human relationships and tackles difficult themes to spark social dialogue. We seek texts that illuminate often-stigmatized social issues and, by bringing them to the forefront, combat their status as taboo or unapproachable. Strange Bird is therefore committed to diverse voices and representation as the truest reflection of human experience. We are comprised of emerging and established artists from a wide range of professions and walks of life. 
This campaign represents a fundraising effort for our first mainstage production, going up this December 14-16th: Ruby Rae Spiegel's Dry Land. A somber, hilarious, difficult investigation into the lives of two adolescent girls on a swim team in small-town Florida, this play represents the complexities of female friendship, sexuality, and body ownership at a time when all control seems to be slipping away.
As a brand-new collective, we are endlessly grateful for any contributions that will aid in honoring this story to its fullest. Donations are a fantastic way to support us, and so is joining us at Shetler Studios this December!

What We Need & What You Get
All donations to this project will go directly towards our production costs, including but not limited to space rental, props, costumes, performance rights, set piece rental, and marketing. Our goal is set at $2,800, which aims to cover not only the aforementioned expenses, but also a bit extra for donation to Planned Parenthood of NYC! (As this play deals with themes of abortion, sexuality, and women's health, we feel it is critical to our mission of socially-conscious theatre to contribute to such non-profit organizations.) Our estimated costs stand at $,2000, at which point any remaining funds will be donated. 
See below for an idea of the difference your contribution can make, and what strange and exciting perks await at various levels of giving. Every donor will receive a shout-out in our program! 

$10 - Freestyle
Buys us small props and costume pieces (goggles, swim caps, the many snacks we consume onstage)
Perks: Our unending love and gratitude! Plus a social media shout-out, and a program thank-you! 


$25 - Backstroke
Buys us multiple costume pieces and additional fun props
Perks: You will be mailed a hand-written love note, and noted in the program!


$50 - Breaststroke
Covers some of our printing and marketing costs (programs, posters, etc.)
Perks: Get a very special thank you as a fellow "Strange Bird" Donor in our program!


$75 - Butterfly
Covers the entire rental for one of our large set pieces 
Perks: In addition to a "Strange Bird" Donor credit, get an original Dry Land poster, designed by our very own Tatyana Aravena, and signed by our cast & crew!


$100 - Dive in
Pays for the production rights for one of our performances! 
Perks: In addition to "Strange Bird" Donor credit, you will receive some colorful, charming, and mischievous original art drawn by Michelle Siracusa.


$250 - Deep End
Covers transportation and set-up expenses for our entire set! 
Perks: In addition to "Strange Bird" Donor credit, you will receive a gift basket with surprise goodies!


$500 - Gold Medal
Covers three days of space rental for our rehearsals and performances! 
Perks: You will receive a Producer credit & two complimentary tickets to the show for the night of your choice!



Please be assured that we plan to mount this very important production regardless of whether we meet our set goal, and all donations will still make an impact! 

The Impact
Dry Land is a story exploring two teenage girls' choices about their lives and bodies at a time when women's stories, sexuality, and bodily autonomy are consistently degraded and devalued in our culture. Bringing their stories to life means not only the chance to provide meaningful, thoughtful entertainment for people, but to spark critical conversations and provide representation onstage that many of us do not get to witness in our everyday lives. We hope that everyone can find power in seeing a piece of themselves recognized in this play. 
On a more long-term scale, your donations are also helping facilitate the launch of Strange Bird as a collective that hopes to exist for many years to come, continuing to produce conversation-sparking theatre and to give voice to diverse human experiences. This is a true grassroots endeavor, and it starts with the support and participation of audience members like yourselves! We want our projects to feel that they belong to everyone! 

Risks & Challenges
Starting a theatre company is no easy task! Dry Land comes with the risks of any first production. Our cast and crew's diverse range of professions and career paths have presented time constraints. As we have no standing funding (yet!), the upfront costs have been high for us, but we are determined to raise that money and more, the difference to be donated to Planned Parenthood. Another challenge of being a newly-minted company is a limited capacity to market and advertise. We are building awareness and support from scratch, and your help is fundamental not only in covering practical costs, but in spreading the word for Strange Bird!
We plan to continue to fundraise through our performance dates in mid-December, and to seek funding from additional sources including small grant programs that are committed to new creative projects. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't donate, there are other great and simple ways you can help:

Spread the word about Strange Bird! If you identify with or are interested in our mission and story, please let your friends and loved ones know! Every listening ear helps, as does every Tweet, Facebook status, and Instagram post! 
Talk loudly about us around the water cooler at work! On your Tinder dates! At Thanksgiving dinner around another strange bird!
Use the Indiegogo share tools! Click those buttons and send our fundraising link to as many people as you can!
COME TO THE SHOW!! BRING A WHOLE ENTOURAGE! This effort means little without audience members to witness it. Our production goes up at Shetler Studios in "The Bridge" at 244 West 54th Street, New York, NY. Show times are as follows: 
Friday, December 14 - 7pm
Saturday, December 15 - 7pm
Sunday, December 16 - 3pm & 7pm



And that's all there is to it. Please help Strange Bird take flight!

story:
OPENS IN DUBLIN, APRIL 14 - 27th 2014!!!

Following the sell-out success of the Agni Acting Studio's 2013 production Dysfunctional Love, we are proud to announce our highly anticipated inaugural 2014 Conservatory Season of three productions. Beginning first with The Lesson by Eugene Ionesco, followed by a pair of short plays by Anton Chekov The Bear and The Proposal, and concluding with Shakespeare's Much Ado About Nothing.

THE PLAY 

In his essay "Experience of the Theatre", Eugene Ionesco claimed to have hated going to the theatre as a child because it gave him "no pleasure or feeling of participation". I share and acknowledge this criticism and strive instead to follow in his footsteps to tell stories that are physical, imaginative, gripping and connect with our audiences. Ionesco would later become known as the father of the Theatre of the Absurd and wrote a number of groundbreaking plays including The Lesson that are simultaneously hilarious, tragic, and profound. In The Lesson Ionesco bravely challenges conventional realism to deliver a play that is utterly gripping and edgy, a play that tantalises with colourful and musical language in a circular plot full of contradictions, ironies and comical constructs. Like Ionesco at Agni we seek to reveal stories that resonate with our common spirit, that boldly connect with our audiences, we share the desire for a distinctly physical and imaginative approach - this embodies the Agni ideal of the relationship between the actors and the audience. 

For me Ionesco was a true artist and he wrote for humanity. Through The Lesson he wanted to awaken us to the meaninglessness of social conventions, the absurdity of bourgeois life  with it's dogmatic and repetitive mechanical nature. He wanted to empower us to think for ourselves, to trust our innate connections with people and to be wary that language is often used as a weapon.  


The Lesson a timid professor uses the meaning he assigns to words to establish tyrannical dominance over an eager pupil. Ionesco employs this ridiculous authoritarian character to expose the false worship of language. The timeless themes explored in The Lesson are perhaps even more relevant today than at the time of it's debut in Paris 1951. As The Observer says 'Ionesco leads us by fantastic paths, back to theatrical basics'.


ABOUT AGNI ACTING STUDIO

In June 2010, Hope Brown opened Agni Acting Studio with six students, a modest startup grant, and a dream. The name Agni, the Sanskrit word for passion, had been suggested by Brown's Mother. The aims of Agni Studio were simple, to train actors in the Stanislavski System and to develop dramatic curricula at secondary schools with the emphasis on building confidence, social awareness and poise with the hope that students would be inspired to go on to teach others.

Over the past four years, Agni has had the pleasure of providing professional acting training to over 100 students and has also produced and developed four sell-out etude productions. A number of students have earned credits on stage and commercials and some have been cast in lead roles in television and film. In the smash hit Irish television series "LOVE/HATE" current and former students John Connors and Peter Coonan play the show's main protagonists and have both worked in released feature films, "King of the Travellers" and "Stalker"; and Barry Keoghan who played Aidan Quinn and Taylor Schilling's troubled son in "Stay" due to be released March 2014 and the character Wayne in "LOVE/HATE". 

Perhaps, most importantly is that we have honoured our initial vow of never turning away a student based on funds, and our students have traded lessons for carpentry, social-media, flyering and even Russian translating.

2014 is a very exciting and important year for the Agni Acting Studio with the establishment of the Agni Conservatory that will bring our productions to the international performing arts community. Looking ahead we hope to begin building our very own theatre-in-the-round here in Dublin in 2015!

                                            
                                                     


TOMAS KIZELIS - director

Tomas was born in Lithuania and holds a M.A. from the Lithuanian Music and Theatre Academy where he received his Masters in Theatre studies under Jonas Vaitkus, director of The Russian Drama Theatre. Additionally he holds a B.A. in the Michael Chekhov method of acting from the Academy. After teaching for the Lithuanian National Youth Theatre for 15 years he returned to the Lithuanian Music and Theatre Academy where he taught the Stanislavski Method and the art of Suzuki Theatre in their graduate program.


HOPE BROWN - producer

Hope is an actor, teacher, producer and Founder of the Agni Acting Studio. Originally from San Diego, California, he spend his youth in the Fiji Islands and New Zealand. Returning to the States, he began his training as an actor and won lead roles in Waiting to Exhale and Terminal Velocity. Since moving to Ireland in 1998, he has trained with the late Deirdre O'Connell of the Focus Theatre and Lee Strasburg Institute. As a performer he has played Caliban for Travelling Lights' Irish National Tour of The Tempest and starred alongside Chris O'Dowd and Johnny Vegas in the critically acclaimed television comedy Moone Boy. National and International stage credits include the world premiere of The Shawshank Redemption, Ireland;  Marc Antony in Julius Caesar, U.S. and Lucius Jenkins in Jesus Hopped The 'A' Train, Irish Premiere, where he receiving critical praise.  Hope is a frequent performer and participant in readings and venues throughout Ireland and the U.S. including: Southwest Shakespeare, The Lir, Trinity College, RTE Radio Drama, The Gaiety, The Black Theatre, The New Theatre and Smock Alley.

WHERE YOUR DONATION GOES

Example of what €6,500 budget for The Lesson gets us:

  • €300 program design and printing
  • €400 royalty fee  
  • €100 publicity photography
  • €250 poster/ flyer/ postcard design and printing
  • €200 insurance
  • €250 paid advertisement
  • €50 costume laundry during run
  • €300 sound design and technician
  • €450 props and costumes 
  • €1000 light rental and designer
  • €1000 set design and construction
  • €2000 theatre rental and rehearsal space

What's unique about this venture is that you will also be supporting an acting school, steeped in the traditions of the art form. If you like the idea of people developing themselves to their highest nature, and challenging themselves through their ideas on stage and through characterisation; if you understand the value in arts entertainment / education that can make one a better, finer, wiser and more useful member of society, I implore you to give generously to this wonderful performing arts school, for these are the very foundations on which it was built upon. 

If we don't reach our entire goal, I'm happy to say I will continue to tirelessly build and invest in my school as I have over the last four years. Just read some of our testimonials to see why!


AGNI ACTING STUDIO TESTIMONIALS

"The moment I ventured into Agni Acting Studio I felt at ease knowing that this was the space where the dream of becoming an actor becomes a reality. As an aspiring performer, I was overcome with fears, vulnerabilities and insecurities. Having completed my first term in the Stanislavski Foundational Course and the following live performance, I have gained more self- confidence, courage and belief as an actor and as an individual. The methodical approach that Hope and Tomas take challenges, encourages and guides you to being a greater actor. All the while they ensure that you remain truthful to the self, keeping the essence of individuality in each stage. It's a warm, homelike environment where you are wrapped in creativity, imagination and understanding, also a whole lot of fun! This atmosphere builds a trust between the fellow actors giving each other endless enthusiasm and support. I shall continue my journey at the Agni Acting Studio, knowing that I will discover more truth, inspiration and adventure that will stay with me forever." 

- Lillian Harris, December 2013.

"I would just like to say that the Stanislavski Studio has been the best experience I have had as an actor...The positive energy and dedication of Hope and Tomas really inspires and motivates you to thrive on the stage and out in the world... It really boosts your confidence and imagination. I would recommend this course to anybody who is interested in acting, weather it be on screen or stage...I am 100% certain you will not regret it. I found that each class was holistic but intense in a positive way... Each class although a group lesson it is also like getting one to one coaching... I will be most definitely continuing my training at the Agni Acting Studio." 

- Stephen Maguire. Proud student of The Agni Acting Studio

Get Involved

PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!! The beautiful thing about technology today is that we can spread the word about this show much faster than we would have been able to do when the "The Lesson" first premiered in 1951. Please share information about our show with your Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Tumblr, Google+, and other social media site followers! "Like" us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, subscribe to us on YouTube, join our circles in Google+!

Thank you!

story:
** check out the "gallery" tab for some pictures and videos of a few things I have done (or at least have video documentation of)  in the last year!**


Dear friends and family,

As you all know, dance is my passion.


I was put in my first dance class at age three, and I haven't left since. 

Devoting all of my time to what I loved to do was never a hard decision for me in grade school. I loved it. I loved going from school to dance class imminently after until late hours in the night. I loved putting work in to something and watching the results change. I loved moving, creating, and working around other people who shared this strangely intense desire to test the limits of their body in the most beautiful way. This drive has never left me. 

Struck with the pressures of an academic university, when I began college was the first time I considered ending my path as a dancing artist and pursuing something more accepted, comfortable, and safe. Trying to double major in dance and biology, then geology, then biopsychology, then English? I couldn't find my place. I didn't know what mattered, what would help the world more, and what would make me happy. 

So, I went with my gut. I left Grand Valley State University and got accepted to Cornish College of the Arts in Seattle, Washington. I learn more and more everyday the power of art, body knowledge, and eliciting proactive change through connecting with your community around creativity. Needless to say, I am happy with my decision, and feel fulfilled everyday as I experience my own passion, and the passion of others for something bigger than themselves. 

Seattle is thriving and inspiring, and it is almost time for me to throw myself out in to the city with my heart on my sleeve. This being said, mastering my craft conceptually calls for an equal task of mastering it physically. This summer, it is only mandatory that I start my professional career, as next year will be my last year in school with the cushion of caring professors and faculty. Doing this,however, is not free. 

I have been accepted to two intensives so far: Strictly Seattle  & Boulder Jazz Dance Workshop. i have been applying to others as well, including a Gaga intensive in New York City. Information on these can be found online with a quick Google search. In short, I will be taking classes in technique, choreography, improvisation, and many other areas while introducing myself to the dance world and even getting to present my own choreography. I hope to attend at least one more intensive, as I find it vital to be as proactive as I can during my last summer as a student. 

Tuition for these 1-2 week intensives can range anywhere from $500-1,000, plus the cost of air fair to each destination. I will be in touch will other dancers, so I should not have to pay for housing. I will be working now and every chance I can get before, after, and in between these intensives. As you can see, I am determined to make these things happen for myself!

I appreciate and thank you for taking the time to read a recap of my story so far, and hope I can continue this story with each year. The smallest donation will help, but if that isn't an option I am still grateful. My email is allison.burke@arts.cornish.edu and I would love to keep anyone who is interested updated on my indeveors, this summer and next year. I would also love to answer any questions, talk about things I've learned, or just say hello!

Thanks so much again! I miss all of my friends and family so dearly and hope to see you soon. 

With love,
Allison

story:
The McAllen Music Theatre Company is a recognized Texas non-profit organization. However, we have not been able to obtain our 501(c)(3) status due to the fees involved. We have our first production coming up, however, most of what we have fundraised will go directly to our show. We still need money to file our application through an attorney. Obtaining our 501(c)(3) status will help us attract more donations since donations would be tax deductible.

For many years, the South Texas area has not had much community support for theatre, music or the arts, but things are changing. Our population is booming and we have had many people relocate to this area from bigger cities and the demand for live theatre is slowly creeping up. The McAllen Music Theatre Company is the only theatrical company which concentrates exclusively on the musical theatre genre in our area.

Please support Musical Theatre and the arts in South Texas by donating to our campaign today!
story_txt:
The McAllen Music Theatre Company is a recognized Texas non-profit organization. However, we have not been able to obtain our 501(c)(3) status due to the fees involved. We have our first production coming up, however, most of what we have fundraised will go directly to our show. We still need money to file our application through an attorney. Obtaining our 501(c)(3) status will help us attract more donations since donations would be tax deductible.
For many years, the South Texas area has not had much community support for theatre, music or the arts, but things are changing. Our population is booming and we have had many people relocate to this area from bigger cities and the demand for live theatre is slowly creeping up. The McAllen Music Theatre Company is the only theatrical company which concentrates exclusively on the musical theatre genre in our area.
Please support Musical Theatre and the arts in South Texas by donating to our campaign today!

story:
Get DC Kids Dancing!

About TWB Community Outreach:

The Washington Ballet (TWB) is asking you to help make the arts accessible to every person in DC.  The Washington Ballet's DanceDC program currently operates in eight DC Public Schools and nearly 400 DC Public School students receive scholarships at The Washington School of Ballet's campus at THEARC in Anacostia, Washington D.C.  In the last ten years, The Washington Ballet has enriched more than 100,000 lives across the District and we are constantly pushing to do more.  

                                  

 

Our Impact:

The Washington Ballet @THEARC and DanceDC programs serve as a home-away-from-home for the underserved children and young adults of the district's poorest wards, where one in three live below the poverty line.  Our programs provide a single location where families can learn, play, exercise, participate in the arts, access heathcare and develop a sense of community.  

                             

 

Not only do these programs bring the arts into the lives of our city's youth, they offer a safe and educational environment for children school.  Dance classes also offer students exposure to structured physical activity in their daily lives, in addition to learning the value of discipline, commitment, self-confidence, collaboration, appreciation of music and the joy of dance.

 

What we need & What you receive

Each year TWB spends more than $400,000 on scholarships throughout the city are 100% funded by donations like these.  To maintain these programs, and plan for their continued growth, The Washington Ballet needs to raise $20,000 by June 17, 2013.  These funds will directly impact the 1,000+ current students of TWB's engagement programs, and ensure continued access to the arts for DC's at-risk communities.

Your generosity will increase access to a variety of opportunities that would become more available for current and future students of The Washington Ballet @THEARC.

These resources include:

  • Funding for a DanceDC teacher at one DC Public School for one year
  • Scholarships for talented DC Public school students to attend The Washington School of Ballet @THEARC
  • Piano accompaniment for students studying at THEARC
  • Provide financial support to increase the number of TWB@THEARC performances

           

 

By supporting The Washington Ballet's community engagement efforts, you will be making a difference to countless families across our Nation's Capital. You will also receive exclusive and unique benefits as a TWB donor, including: access to special behind-the-scenes tours, invitations to intimate events with company dancers, and even a chance to appear on stage in a performance of The Nutcracker!

story:
Happy Spring, friends & supporters!

As The Physical Plant enters its third year, I think about what we were able to create last year thanks to the support of so many.  Please enjoy the video of The Physical Plant's 2012 performances above-- our work is for you and because of you!

With a group of such talented, intelligent dancers, The Physical Plant has grown.  We've been pushing one another's performance boundaries and enjoying the creative process; embracing the unknown and allowing dances to breathe a life of its own. 

We have already been working in the studio, expanding last year's Currents and planning new works with video and text, comedy and installation.  We have applied to several dance festivals and programs this season, and are waiting to hear back! 

Please help bring our new works to life so The Physical Plant can flourish even more this year!  

                                    

About The Physical Plant

The Physical Plant is comprised of various collaborators where we develop the changing nuances of the mind-body connection.  We focus a technical eye on our instinctive movements, and study how intention drives us.  By manipulating this language, we grow from understanding how the body speaks while sharing our ideas with audiences to open a dialogue.

                                            

Your Donations Work!

Months of creating, rehearsing, and production planning go on behind any single performance.  Ticket sales alone cannot off-set company costs even on a minimal budget.  Of utmost important to me is to be able to offer my dancers a stipend for their dedication and hard work-- without them, there is no medium for choreography. 

Our goal this year is to raise $2000.  Your donation directly helps fund all dancers' rehearsal and performance stipends, rehearsal space, and performance production costs.  If we cannot reach our fundraising goal, our dance works will have to be tabled and our momentum will be stalled until we find sufficient financial backing. 

When you donate, you get PERKS!  Choose from the PERKS tiers on the right!

 *Note:  Surpassing our fundraising goal allows our company to receive the full $2000 after service fees! *

Why Donate (besides perks)?

Your donations are the jumping off point for the dance company to build its own economy.  The dance industry relies majorly on private funding to keep offering art to the general public.  In the bigger picture, your donations bring opportunity to dancers, choreographers, and dance aficionados alike. We love what we do as dancers and believe in its societal value.  With your support, we can continue to work hard to make quality dance pieces that reach audiences.

                                  

If you can't contribute, know someone who can?

It's all about who you know, right?  Even if you can't contribute, your support is so appreciated.  If you have any dance-loving friends or know anyone philanthropic, please tell them about our cause! 

 

THANK YOU SINCERELY FOR YOUR SUPPORT!      

~Karesia, choreographer The Physical Plant

story:
Sponsor us now

  • My name is Joseph Fa'afiu - I am the 2017 Winner of Toastmasters New Zealand International Speech Contest. As the winner I will be representing New Zealand in Vancouver, Canada at the World Championship.
  • Our campaign is to simple get my wife Lydia and I to the World Championship of Public Speaking and to cover flights, accommodation, travel and travel visa. 
  • In doing so you will allow me to fulfil a life-long dream to represent New Zealand on the World stage. It will also allow my wife who is my No.1 supporter to be there with me every step of the way. I have fulfilled one dream, but another is to become the first ever Polynesian World Champion of Public Speaking - win or lose - I will give it my all.

Where will the funds will go?

  • The money will go towards the following (New Zealand Dollar): 
  • Travel Visa = $250; Flights = $4,586; Accommodation = $1,872; Convention Cost = $1,660

  • Food = $1000; Transport = $500 - this will all be converted to Canadian Dollars

Risks & Challenges

The risk is that we won't get enough and we can't go, but we won't stop until we reach our target.

story:
"Art is not a mirror held up to reality but a hammer with which to shape it."         

-Bertolt Brecht

The Life of Jude is a play I am passionate about. Every time I picked up the script I said "There is something here. This play is important.” I have worked on it for over ten years. I developed it through the Tarragon Theatre, The Shaw Festival, Theatre Passe Muraille, George Brown Theatre School and the National Theatre School of Canada. But none of those illustrious institutions are producing the play; I am, with my little company Falling Hammer at the Summerworks Theatre Festival - August 8-18, 2013. With 21 actors all working for free, this will be the largest show in Summerworks history.

We are seeking your support to help put this impressive show on stage and to put money into the pockets of the artists involved.

The Challenge

The play is a parable about a boy who thinks he's chosen by God and through the misapplication of his beliefs, ends up sowing tragedy all around him. It is also extremely funny, has a love story, explores theatrical form and features 21 performers on stage in an Epic Theatre style musical.

This play is so large that most theatres cannot afford to produce it and yet we are  compelled to mount it amidst the two and three handers that make up most of our theatrical fare.

To produce this play "normally" with union fees and insurance based on 7 weeks work would be a minimum 150k budget. Havng a big dream play produced even with sold out houses for 7 performances at Summerworks means each artist will make only a modest remuneration for all their hard work. We are seeking to augment this through our Indiegogo campaign where all money raised will go directly into the artist's pockets.   Help make our dream come true and support these fine artist's efforts.

SYNOPSIS

The Life of Jude is about militarism, corporatism, greed, faith and love. In a mountain town called Hope, long ago (and right now) Jude, a young boy loses his father and mother and is sent to a church seminary to provide him an education and vocation.

Jude’s questioning mind is controlled by a strict clergy who ply him with fundamentalist teachings, hardening his beliefs. Jude returns to Hope as a priest after finishing his studies. As he works to save the souls of his parish, his beliefs come into conflict with the world around him and his feeling for the woman he left behind.

I have been a playwright and actor for over 25 years and have had my work produced nationally and internationally and yet producing my own work is the most satisfying work of all. I wrote this play to explore greed, violence and religious fundamentalism, believing that all religions need to balance the human with the divine if there is to be peace and tolerance.  I feel privileged to be putting this play up in Summerworks with such a distinguished group.

My Co-Artistic Director Kelly Thornton and I have a stellar record producing several Dora nominated plays and attracting critical acclaim for our work. We are committed to producing this play in August 2013 and providing a compelling and powerful production. 

The play features twelve of Toronto’s most explosive and accomplished actors, in the company of eight talented members of the 2013 graduating class of the National Theatre School and Bishop’s University along with my impressive six year old daughter.

The Company

Sehar Bhojani, Christopher Blades, Kevin Bundy, Steve Cumyn, Shannon Currie, Bruce Dow, Paul Dunn, Grace Fitzpatrick, Stephane Garneau-Monten, Darcy Gerhart, Hardee T. Lineham, Alex Plouffe, Chloe Poch-Goldin, Dylan Roberts, Adrian Shepherd-Gawinski, Pamela Sinha, Jeffrey R. Smith, Jeremiah Sparks, Adam Kenneth Wilson, Maurice Dean Wint, Richard Zeppieri   

Alex Poch-Goldin Playwright, David Ferry Director

Jesse LaVercombe Composer, Adrian Shepherd-Gawinski Musical Director

Glenn Davidson Set Design, Bonnie Beecher Lighting Design

Kendra Terpenning/Cat Haywood Costume Design 

Raha Javanfar Projection Design, Samantha Adams Stage Manager

Ash Knight Assistant Director, Kelly Thornton Producer 

It really is an impressive company presenting a bold and beautiful play that speaks to universal themes. We hope that you will support our endeavors to bring this project to life. We can offer some modest perks for your support and all monies will be applied to artist's fees. 

Thank you for your support and interest.

Sincerely

Alex Poch-Goldin

story:
Why donate?

Very often, a Prix de Lausanne Prize Winner must do his/her own crowdfunding platform to be able to pay for the expenses to get to his/her partner school or company. Thanks to your help, the dream will much more easily come true for one dancer ;)

1. Help the Audience Favourite Prize Winner of the Prix de Lausanne 2018 to pay for his/her travel, hotel and food to get to his/her chosen partner school or company!

2. Contribute to open the doors to the world’s finest schools and companies for this young dancer,

3. Contribute to the mission of the Prix de Lausanne which is to reveal the potential of exceptionally talented young dancers from around the globe by having them perform in front of a jury composed of world-renowned dance personalities.

What is the Audience Favourite Prize?

This prize reflects an “instant preference” that the audience has felt for one of the finalists on the day of the Finals itself. The audience votes by SMS in the venue or on the ARTE Concert website. Contrary to the prizes awarded by the jury based on an evaluation system spanning several days, the Audience Favourite reflects the emotions of the moment. This prize rewards the finalist having earned the most votes expressed by the audience.

---

Pourquoi faire un don ?

Très souvent, les lauréats du Prix de Lausanne doivent faire leur propre campagne de récolte de fonds pour pouvoir payer les frais liés à l'intégration dans leur nouvelle école ou compagnie partenaire. Grâce à votre aide, le lauréat 2018 du Prix du Public pourra plus facilement réaliser son rêve !

1. Soutenez le jeune danseur qui remportera le Prix du Public lors de la prochaine Finale du Prix de Lausane 2018, en participant à ses frais de voyage, de logement et de repas pour sa rentrée dans l’école ou la compagnie partenaire qu'il/elle aura choisi(e).

2. Aider à ouvrir les portes des plus grandes écoles et compagnies de danse du monde à ce jeune danseur!

3. Contribuez à la mission du Prix de Lausanne qui est de révéler le potentiel exceptionnel de jeunes danseurs du monde entier en leur donnant l'opportunité de se présenter devant un jury composé des plus grands noms de la danse !

Qu'est-ce que le Prix du Public ?

Ce prix est l’expression d’un coup de coeur que le public aura eu pour l’un/e des finalistes. Le public vote par SMS dans la salle du Théâtre de Beaulieu ou via le site d’ARTE Concert. Contrairement aux prix attribués par le jury selon un système d’évaluation portant sur plusieurs jours, le Prix du Public reflète l’émotion du moment ;) Ce prix est décerné au/à la finaliste qui remporte le plus de voix exprimées par le public !

story:
About Gateway High School and Summer Blackbox Series

The Gateway Theatre Program has seen many successes in the past five years and seeks to expand its educational and artistic outreach beyond the academic year into the Summer Season.

This Summer they are planning to team up with a new organization Nothin' Producitons to create this amazing Black Box series.

All four shows will be performed in the Gateway High School Performing Art Center.

The season auditions will be open to the public!

The Plays

Biloxi Blues by Neil Simon

Winner of the 1985 Tony for Best Play

When we last met Eugene Jerome, he was coping with adolescence in 1930's Brooklyn. Here, he is a young army recruit during WW II, going through basic training and learning about Life and Love with a capital 'L' along with some harsher lessons, while stationed at boot camp in Biloxi, Mississippi in 1943.

Boeing Boeing by Marc Carmoletti

 This 1960's French farce adapted for the English-speaking stage features self-styled Parisian lothario Bernard, who has Italian, German, and American fiancees, each beautiful airline hostesses with frequent "layovers". He keeps "one up, one down and one pending" until unexpected schedule changes bring all three to Paris and Bernard's apartment at the same time

Rabbit Hole by David Lindsay-Abaire

Pulitzer Prize Winner 2007

Becca and Howie Corbett have everything a family could want, until a life-shattering accident turns their world upside down and leaves the couple drifting perilously apart. RABBIT HOLE charts their bittersweet search for comfort in the darkest of places and for a path that will lead them back into the light of day.

The Children's Hour by Lillian Hellman

A serious and adult play about two women who run a school for girls. After a malicious youngster starts a rumor about the two women, the rumor soon turns to scandal. As the young girl comes to understand the power she wields, she sticks by her story, which precipitates tragedy for the women. 

Meet the Directors

Donald Rupe (Directing Boeing Boeing and Rabbit Hole) has been the Theatre Director for Gateway High School for six years and it is under his guidance that GHS Theatre has achieved great successes on the district and state levels achieving multiple Best in Shows, Critics Choice, and two Mainstage selections for the Florida Thespian Festival.

Armando Rivera (Directing Biloxi Blues) is a recent graduate of Florida Gulf Coast University with a B.A. in Theatre and a graduate of Gateway High School from the class of 2009.

Vishal Seemangal (Directing The Childrens Hour) is a recent graduate of Gateway High School class of 2013.

 

Budget Breakdown

Your support will get us the minimum amount of money we need to pay for the show royalties and copies of the scripts.

 

Biloxi Blues = $375

Boeing Boeing = $300

Rabbit Hole = $225

The Children' Hour = $225

= $1125 Royalties

+ $275 for Scripts

+ $100 for props

= $1500

 

This is of course the minimum amount of money we need to produce these shows. Any further contributions will go to funding other technical elements such as

costumes, props, and sets.

What You Get

Take a look at the side panel to see our exciting rewards!

All contributions will be in support of local artists creating engaging theatre in the Central Florida Community and of course the knowledge that a very special kind of theatre is being made in part by YOU!

The Impact

Our hope with this season is to give the community an experience unlike what has been offered before in the area. 

We want to continue to foster educational opportunities for the young artists of Central Florida during the summer months and to also begin a collaborative sharing experience in creative process with the community here in Kissimmee/St. Cloud/Orlando.

Other Ways You Can Help

SHARE SHARE SHARE!! Even if you can't contribute share our information on facebok, twitter, instagram tumblr, Vine or whatever secret social media you use!
story_txt:
About Gateway High School and Summer Blackbox Series
The Gateway Theatre Program has seen many successes in the past five years and seeks to expand its educational and artistic outreach beyond the academic year into the Summer Season.
This Summer they are planning to team up with a new organization Nothin' Producitons to create this amazing Black Box series.
All four shows will be performed in the Gateway High School Performing Art Center.
The season auditions will be open to the public!
The Plays
Biloxi Blues by Neil Simon
Winner of the 1985 Tony for Best Play
When we last met Eugene Jerome, he was coping with adolescence in 1930's Brooklyn. Here, he is a young army recruit during WW II, going through basic training and learning about Life and Love with a capital 'L' along with some harsher lessons, while stationed at boot camp in Biloxi, Mississippi in 1943.
Boeing Boeing by Marc Carmoletti
 This 1960's French farce adapted for the English-speaking stage features self-styled Parisian lothario Bernard, who has Italian, German, and American fiancees, each beautiful airline hostesses with frequent "layovers". He keeps "one up, one down and one pending" until unexpected schedule changes bring all three to Paris and Bernard's apartment at the same time
Rabbit Hole by David Lindsay-Abaire
Pulitzer Prize Winner 2007
Becca and Howie Corbett have everything a family could want, until a life-shattering accident turns their world upside down and leaves the couple drifting perilously apart. RABBIT HOLE charts their bittersweet search for comfort in the darkest of places and for a path that will lead them back into the light of day.
The Children's Hour by Lillian Hellman
A serious and adult play about two women who run a school for girls. After a malicious youngster starts a rumor about the two women, the rumor soon turns to scandal. As the young girl comes to understand the power she wields, she sticks by her story, which precipitates tragedy for the women. 
Meet the Directors
Donald Rupe (Directing Boeing Boeing and Rabbit Hole) has been the Theatre Director for Gateway High School for six years and it is under his guidance that GHS Theatre has achieved great successes on the district and state levels achieving multiple Best in Shows, Critics Choice, and two Mainstage selections for the Florida Thespian Festival.
Armando Rivera (Directing Biloxi Blues) is a recent graduate of Florida Gulf Coast University with a B.A. in Theatre and a graduate of Gateway High School from the class of 2009.
Vishal Seemangal (Directing The Childrens Hour) is a recent graduate of Gateway High School class of 2013.
 
Budget Breakdown


Your support will get us the minimum amount of money we need to pay for the show royalties and copies of the scripts.
 
Biloxi Blues = $375
Boeing Boeing = $300
Rabbit Hole = $225
The Children' Hour = $225
= $1125 Royalties
+ $275 for Scripts
+ $100 for props
= $1500
 
This is of course the minimum amount of money we need to produce these shows. Any further contributions will go to funding other technical elements such as 
costumes, props, and sets.
What You Get
Take a look at the side panel to see our exciting rewards!
All contributions will be in support of local artists creating engaging theatre in the Central Florida Community and of course the knowledge that a very special kind of theatre is being made in part by YOU!


The Impact
Our hope with this season is to give the community an experience unlike what has been offered before in the area. 
We want to continue to foster educational opportunities for the young artists of Central Florida during the summer months and to also begin a collaborative sharing experience in creative process with the community here in Kissimmee/St. Cloud/Orlando.
Other Ways You Can Help


SHARE SHARE SHARE!! Even if you can't contribute share our information on facebok, twitter, instagram tumblr, Vine or whatever secret social media you use!

story:
As a group of actors, directors and producers in New York City, we strive to make theatre accessible and enjoyable for all audiences! Our backgrounds range from Off-Broadway, to Comedy, to Broadway and we are thrilled to be creating this exciting piece of theatre. We are not out to make a profit, we are out to have fun and entertain. Because of this, there are expenses we need to cover, and would LOVE your help! 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Our goal is to raise between $4,000-$5,000. Why? Actor costs, space costs, legal rights, etc.
  • Wanna donate? Great! We have a few perks...

              $10 donation gets you a thank you in the program
              $25 donation gets you a thank you + 1 ticket + 1 drink ticket
              $50 donation gets you a thank you + 2 tickets + 2 drink tickets
              $75 donation gets you a thank you + 3 tickets + 3 drink tickets
              $100 donation gets you a thank you + 4 tickets + 4 drink tickets

 

Putting on a show from scratch is never easy, but with your help, we are sure to make it a memorable and fun evening!

Can't contribute? No problem! We totally get it. Other ways you can help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our show and Indiegogo campaign.
  • Come see our show! Tickets available here.

story:
Who we are...

Hubbard Hall is a regional arts center in upstate New York dedicated to bringing the best of theater, music, dance and visual arts to our region.   We present actors and singers from across the world and have received numerous grants and awards, including the American Prize for quality productions and recently a Solomon Foundation grant for an overhaul of our lighting system.  

Our founding director and otherwise fearless leader, Benjie White, retires this year.  

Benjie has contributed so much of himself to this space during his tenure, but one thing he does often goes unrecognized.  For the past thirty-seven years he lovingly and painstakingly has hand built and painted wooden risers for every show in every configuration imaginable - in the round, thrust, proscenium and so on.  

For every new production, there is a thrill of excitement when you walk up the Hubbard Hall stairs and wonder what surprise of a set is awaiting you on the other side of the door.  Which side of our old opera house will you be facing this time?  How close to the performers are you?  Do they surround you, are they onstage, under the balcony, runnning down the center? That magic is, in no small part, thanks to Benjie's risers.  

Having the ability to transform the space is a key to our success with audiences, but this process has historically taken countless days of building and moving heavy wooden platforms to accomplish and isn't sustainable moving forward.  

What we need...

In order to keep this magic, but reduce the manpower, we need a metal riser system that would allow us to change over more easily and quickly, giving us greater capacity to use the space and cutting down on the hours it would take to do so.  The more flexible system would give artists, audiences and community members greater access and use of the Hall for many years to come.  It is a needed improvement and would be an excellent way to send Benjie off, feeling his job was finally completed.

Most riser systems are out of our budget, but we have recently received a quote of $20,000 for a new metal system that would provide us with greater flexibility and capacity.  AND we have a generous donor who has offered a $10,000 match if we can raise the rest ourselves.  

Here's the catch: we need to make the move on this in the next week if we want to have these risers in place this year and make use of this match.  In order for us to make the big decision to move forward now, we need a show of support from YOU for about half of the match amount in record time.  That's $5,000 this week, and there are some cool perks attached for donors too.  Can we do it?  Believe, Sancho...

You make a difference!

Contributions start as low as $10, and yes, even that amount is important.  Just as important though is spreading the word- facebook us and email your friends.  Let's get some grass roots funding started and make art and community happen!

story:
Hi! My name is Tyler Bueno, I'm one of the directors and writers for Fairy Tail: IRL. The show is made out of fun and love for the anime and the manga.

The story centers around Natsu, Lucy, Gray, Erza, and Happy as they are sent on this wacky journey and end up in reality. The show is very audience interactive and full of laughs and even some tears.

We need at the minimum $300 for accurate costumes, props and equipment to run the show.

The show runs October 28th through the 30th. And then one other show at Vision Con in February.

story:
The Los Angeles Women’s Theatre Project is Celebrating Five Years of Creating Opportunities for Women In The Performing Arts.

“The word theatre comes from the Greeks. It means the seeing place. It is the place people come to see the truth about life and the social situation." … Stella Adler.

Theatre has always been a reflection of who we are as a society, a culture and a community, which is why there is a serious problem when only 20% of the perspectives and stories that are told are created by women.   Women purchase 70% of the tickets, they’re 60% of the audience and yet despite 50% of the play submissions to theatres being written by women, only 20% of the creative works that end up on the stage actually have female writers.

The Los Angeles Theatre Project (LAWTP) was founded in 2007 as a 501 C3 nonprofit organization to create opportunities for gender equity in theatre and the Performing Arts.  We create educational opportunities and performances that represent women on a broader scale and meet the needs of our culture, mentoring young girls and providing support to women in all phases of their careers.  We support women in achieving their goals and their dreams through networking, referrals, productions, promotion and education. 

In the five years since our founding, we have created and presented an annual festival of New Works each fall and produced multiple live productions written and directed by women, in addition to providing many educational opportunities, workshops, classes and presentations in all aspects of the performing arts. To continue our mission we need your contribution.

 

What We Need

We’re raising $14,000 to produce the 4th Annual 20% New Works Festival. 

This money will cover:

  • Theatre rental and rehearsal space for 15 shows
  • Equipment rentals, set, prop and miscellaneous requirements for 15 shows
  • Producer
  • Sound & Light Engineers.  
  • Actor’s, Directors, Stage Crew (includes stipends for approx. 40 individuals)
  • Parking (it’s Hollywood) for all casts, directors, volunteers.
  • Marketing, Promotion, Advertising, Public Relations

Thank you for your contribution.

The Impact

The 20% New Works Festival is an annual tradition that provides creative outlets for women from all over the country. This campaign will establish opportunities for over 200 artists in the Performing Arts. We provide women, a greatly underserved population in theatre, the chance to present their works and talents and to enable a more gender balanced perspective to be presented to the Los Angeles Community.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Spread the word, attend our wonderful theatre productions or Volunteer at the event.  CONTACT: deejaecox@lawomenstheatreproject.com

story:
Fjord is a house team that formed at the Philly Improv Theater (PHIT) in January 2015. We specialize in taking any audience suggestion and turning into a reason to display our garbage hearts and fill our emotional voids with sweet laughter. Our dream has always been to take our show to an international stage, and we finally have the chance to do it! Canada has opened its arms by inviting us to the Vancouver International Improv Festival (VIIF 2016), but it's far too far for road-tripping and we'll need some help getting there!

From weekly practices to Saturday night shows, we love devoting the majority of our time to building our craft and engaging with our weird, Philly comedy community. This festival will not only give us a chance to show off all of our hard work to fresh eyes, but will also be a way to represent our beloved Philly on an international stage. #VIIF2016

We Are Fjörd

 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise as close to $4,000 as we can so that all 7 of us can fly to Canada and have someplace cheap & safe to sleep for the nights we have to be there.

All of the funds will go only to travel and stay. If any amount is somehow left over, we will donate it to help fund performance arts for children in Philadelphia. No matter what, your hard-earned and generously given dollars will absolutely be going to the arts. 

You WILL be rewarded for your kindness. In addition to keeping you updated about our trip, we have goodies all set up for you so you have something physical in return to hold/wear/stroke while you miss us on our big, international trip.  Like our new, Philly-inspired t-shirt!

Other Ways You Can Help

We love attention even more than we love money. So if you can't contribute dollars, you can always:

Share this campaign with as many people as you can!

Like our page and continue being updated on our trip!

story:
Contribute this week to support International Women's Day!

Fame was within reach…until Pearl stole the show.

Winging My Way to the Top is about sibling rivalry, egos and a second chance at the big time.

This is a brand new Australian musical comedy written by a couple of housewives from Canberra.  OK, admittedly one runs her own business but you will be reassured to learn the other one is a chronic underachiever. 



WHO ARE THESE WOMEN?

After meeting at the Canberra School of Music (Jazz Studies), Karen Strahan and Jill Walsh have independently collaborated, performed and co-produced successful cabaret productions for the past 20 years. During this time they have been fortunate enough to con some of Australia’s leading directors, musicians and vocalists to jump on the creative bandwagon. “Hey guys!  We’ve got this great idea!!!!”

WHEN IS THIS SHOW GOING ON?

Overture, dim the lights, this is it… the night of nights. The 8th of May 2014 for a two-week season. 

Closing night is the 18th May 2014… and oh what heights we’ll hit… on with the show this is it.

WHERE IS THIS SHOW GOING ON AND HOW DID THAT HAPPEN?

Winging My Way to the Top will be seen for the very first time at The Q – Queanbeyan Performing Arts Centre NSW… just a little off Broadway.

In February 2012 two very nervous girls (GIRLS: Aust. A female from the age of infancy to the age of death) pitched their completely original show to the Program Manager/Artistic Director, Stephen Pike in the foyer of The Q Theatre. Yep, you guessed it, they wang it!  (WANG: Aust. past tense of winging.)

WHAT WE NEED

We need you!  Help us raise $30,000 of the $120,000 needed to put the show on.  As independent producers Strahan and Walsh have to finance theatre costs, musical arrangements, musician fees, sound recording, set and lighting design and staff, costumes, marketing, publicity and printing.

While we’ve been treading the cabaret boards for many years we need you to step into the spotlight and become a part of making Winging My Way to the Top a smash hit!  Who knows, Queanbeyan today, tomorrow Cobargo! 

WHAT’S IN IT FOR YOU?

Comedy, escapism and a bit of fun for starters.  We want you to be a feather in the wings of this bird.  Help us get it off the ground. Award winning Director Stephen Pike, plans to invite producers nationwide to the season in May 2014 to help launch the musical nationally, so who knows where it could end up and you can say to everyone – you were responsible for making it happen.  You were there at the crucial start when the show needed you most.

Check out the tiering to see the varied and exciting rewards you can get. They range from promotional material for the show, copies of the soundtrack, tickets to any show and tickets to opening and closing night while they’re available (including the all-important after party!), exclusive dinner with the cast and private performances by four members of the cast (who make up vocal act The Marvellous Mizdemeanours)! 

AWARDS AND GRANTS

Winging My Way to the Top has just received an Arts ACT grant of:
$34,452 to assist in staging the production.

We are very thankful to have the support of the ACT Government and the recognition of Canberra based artists.

In 2012, the show also won: 

a Capital Arts Patron Organisation (CAPO) Macquarie Wealth Award of $4,000, which will assist in the cost of the set design. 

ENDORSEMENTS

“Two highly talented, wildly enthusiastic and very clever Canberra women are soon to venture into new territory by producing Winging My Way to the Top. The new musical is anticipated with relish. History demonstrates this will be another successful venture undertaken by these two inventive ladies and I heartily recommend supporting this project.” Ian McLean AM, CSC 2013 (Theatre Musical Director who has conducted nearly 30 productions including Les Miserables and Phantom of the Opera).

“I am very impressed with Karen and Jill’s ability to write funny, believable characters with which audiences immediately identify. Winging My Way to the Top is a delightful extension of the writing skills of these independent producers and an excellent piece of commercial writing, offering strong potential to become a Broadway hit. I have no hesitation recommending it.” Bill Stephens Theatre Critic 2013

THE TEAM

Some of the best artists, technicians and musicians from Canberra are on this team and they are committed to making the World premiere of Winging My Way to the Top a success.

Producers – Karen Strahan and Jill Walsh

Director - Stephen Pike

Musical Director and Arranger - John Black

Publicist – Coralie Wood

Choreographer - Jordan Kelly

Costume Designer – Christine Pawlicki (Christine’s Place, Erindale)

Set Designer – Wayne Shepherd

Graphic Designer – Gaye Reid (Let’s Create)

Lighting Designer – Kelly McGannon, Adrian Rytir

Sponsorship Liaison Manager – Angela Lount (Funky Fedoras)

Crowd Fund Campaign Manager - Daniel Sanguineti

Production Manager/Stage Manager – Samantha Barrett

Project Manager – Kathy Sly


THE CAST

The Diamond Sisters


Jill Walsh – plays Beryl Cheapside


Karen Strahan – plays Ruby Diamond


Lisa McClelland – plays Pearl Diamond,


David Pearson – plays life partner to Ruby - Godfrey Goldsmith


Gordon Nicolson – plays husband to Beryl - Charlie Cheapside


Gaye Reid – plays neighbour Phyllis Jones


Angela Lount – plays French maid Vivyen Yves-St-Monternad-Roussseau


MUSICIANS

John Black -  MD, Pianist and Arranger

James Luke – Double Bass

Alec Coulson – Double and Electric Bass

Derrick Brassington – Drums and Percussion

Anton Wurzer – Piano Accordion and Synthesiser

Greg Stott – Electric Guitar

Stuart King – Electric Guitar

Dan McLean – Trumpet

Cameron Scott – Trumpet

Jo Taylor – Saxophone

Tony Hunter – Sound Engineer and Guitar

Soundtrack recorded at Artsound Studio Manuka


PITCH VIDEO FILM CREW AND TALENT

Daniel Sanguineti – Director/Video Producer

Michael Watson - Producer/Prod. Assistance

Miguel Gallagher – Director of Photographer

Jeremy Lasek – plays Dan Straight

Maija Zunde – plays Ali Katz

Our daughters and niece:

Samantha Williams – plays young Beryl Diamond

Sarah Bradley – plays young Ruby Diamond

Eliza Francisco– plays young Pearl Diamond

Special thanks to

Hawker Primary School for the use of their state of the art hall

Tom Williams (and the homeboys) for lending their penthouse for filming the back-story.

Margaret Boyes – volunteer and catering.

Deb Ashcroft - volunteer


SPONSORS

musical is anticipated with relish. History demonstrates this will be another
successful venture undertaken by these two inventive ladies and I heartily
recommend supporting this project.” Ian
McLean AM, CSC 2013 (Theatre Musical Director who has conducted nearly 30
productions including Les Miserables and Phantom of the Opera).
 “I am very impressed with Karen and Jill’s ability
to write funny, believable characters with which audiences immediately
identify. Winging My Way to the Top is a delightful extension of the writing
skills of these independent producers and an excellent piece of commercial
writing, offering strong potential to become a Broadway hit. I have no
hesitation recommending it.” Bill
Stephens Theatre Critic 2013

Some of the best artists, technicians and musicians from Canberra are
on this team and they are committed to making the World premiere of Winging My Way to the Top
a success.
